column2: MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 7--One of the district's younger golf stars, Miss Grace Amory of Women's National, gained the final of the women's metropolitan championship today and will face Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches in the thirty-six-hole test over the Montclair Golf Club course tomorrow.
CHUNGKING, China, June 7-- Fierce fighting raged today on the west bank of the Han River, as Chinese troops resisted the efforts of Japanese Forces to advance on Ichang and Shasi.
Residential leasing activity reported yesterday by brokers and agents was well distributed throughout the city, East Side and Greenwich Village buildings being well represented.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Manton Richter of 1158 Fifth Avenue will give a dinner dance on Nov. 28 at the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Patricia Richter. The debutante was graduated from the Chapin School yesterday.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 7-- Approximately 500 members of the Bond Club of New York participated today in the twentieth annual field day of the club at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here.

ROME, June 7--Italy remained at the side lines today watching the result of the battle in France. Once that great struggle reaches its climax, the danger of Premier Mussolini's moving will obviously be great.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 7--Champion Halcyon Singleton, owned by the Halcyon Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Clark of this town, today captured the leading honors in the Summer specialty show of the Welsh Terrier Club of America.

RUTLAND, Vt., June 7 (AP)-- Frank Gannett, newspaper publisher and candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, called tonight for a $500,000,000 Congressional appropriation to purchase the nation's surplus agricultural produce to aid starving European war victims.
Steps were taken yesterday leading toward utilization of the facilities of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., for the manufacture of arms. The company has plants at Toledo, Ohio, and Maywood, Calif.

There will be some exciting fishing in at least two of New Jersey's lakes today, for the annual junior sportsmen's fishing contest is scheduled to attract scores of anglers under 14 to Sunrise Lake at Red Bank and the lake at Spring Lake.
A class of twenty-five boys received diplomas last night at the thirty-third annual commencement exercises of the Riverdale Country School, held on the campus in Riverdale.

CINCINNATI, June 7--Two winning streaks crossed paths today, and when the echoes of the collision died away in the eleventh inning the Dodgers were leading the National League by 21 percentage points and their victory string was stretched to six games.

CLEVELAND, June 7--The first sad sight observed on the Canterbury course today was Jimmy Demaret, the Texas sharpshooter who was supposed to knock 'em dead in this open championship, going so badly that he was trying to hide in his own gallery.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller of the City of New York, was the guest at what was described as a "bachelor luncheon" given by the Municipal Forum in the Railroad Club, 30 Church Street, yesterday.
The first meeting of the Northeastern Jurisdictional Conference of the newly united Methodist Church will be held in Atlantic City, N.J., beginning on June 18.

WASHINGTON, June 7--President Roosevelt outlined plans today for trading in old weapons for new under a program which would make the old ones immediately available for resale by manufacturers to France and Great Britain.

HUBOKEN, N.J., June 7-- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, will give the address tomorrow morning at the sixty-eighth annual commencement of Stevens Institute of Technology, here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7--Newspapers were praised today by Dr. William Lyon Phelps at Jefferson Medical College commencement exercises as institutions for increasing vitality and combating "despondency and gloom."

TRENTON, N.J., June 7 (AP)-- Captain John J. Lamb of the New Jersey State Police, who played an important role in the investigations of the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby and Hall-Mills murder case, died today at his home in near-by Titusville after a year's illness. His age was 47.
Home Owners Loan Corporation holdings figured largely in the Brooklyn realty sales reported yesterday.

Twenty-six days after his Panzerdivisionen were hurled against the Low Countries on May 10, Hitler launched last week a new attack in an attempt to knock out France.
For the first time in this country French baccalaureate examinations took place at the Lycee Francais de New York, 3 East Ninety-fifth Street, this week.

MADRID, June 8--Sir Samuel Hoare, the new British Ambassador, this morning presented his credentials to Generalissimo Francisco Franco in the former Royal Palace. Many police were stationed in the square in front of the palace.

The Fair announced yesterday that cash prizes totaling $3,000 will be awarded in the "America Through the Needle's Eye" contest being conducted in cooperation with various department stores throughout the country. The winning entries in sectional contests will be judged at the Fair about Aug. 1.

The eleventh annual national piano playing tournament sponsored by the National Guild of Piano Teachers in the Hotel Biltmore ended yesterday after four days of auditions. During the day 120 pianists were heard, making about 400 for the four sessions.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Edward Young of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Margaret Young, to the Rev. Charles Flint Kellogg, rector of the Protes tant Episcopal Church of the Mediator, Kingsbridge Avenue and 231st Street, son of Mrs. Charles T. Kellogg and the late Mr. Kellogg of Great Barrington, Mass.

The Senior Middle Atlantic A. A. U. track and field championships for men are to be held on June 15, at Ocean City, N. J. The following day, the Manhattan Athletic League is to sponsor a meet at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8--Cablegrams and letters received today at the office of the American Friends Service Committee here gave graphic descriptions of the situation facing relief workers in France, offering some idea of the gigantic task facing American relief organizations in caring for 3,500,000 or more new refugees.

The 35,000-ton North Carolina, second battleship to be launched in this country in two weeks, will go down the ways at the navy yard in Brooklyn next Thursday at 4:15 P. M., it was announced yesterday by Navy offiicals, who said that a crowd of 30,000 persons, all of...
THE laws of the American Contract Bridge League pro hibit betting on tournament results, but it is not for that reason that there is very little gambling in tournament play.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Provisional reports on the population in thirty-one cities of 25,000 or more based on the 1940 census show an increase of 6.3 per cent in the decade ended with this year, compared with a 23 per cent gain for the same communities in the previous decade, the Census Bureau stated today.
BUENOS AIRES (By Air Mail)-- Because school children with empty stomachs are not the best students of today or the best citizens of tomorrow, Argentina is now operating ...
Congress considered measures on a broad front last week to strengthen the defenses of the United States and to promote hemisphere security.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP)The Eastern sectional women's tennis team from the New York City area captured the Eleonora R. Sears Trophy today by upsetting the favored New England team, defending champion, 5-4, in the final round at the Germantown Cricket Club.

BOSTON, June 8--Frederick Shepherd Converse, noted composer, for mer dean of the New England Conservatory of Music and former Professor of Music at Harvard, died today at his home, 267 Fox Hill Road, Westwood. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 8--About 100 heavily armed attack planes, especially designed to harass enemy troops from low altitudes, have earmarked by the War Department for possible fighting in France, under the Administration's "trade-in" arrangement for Army and Navy planes.

Nine homes have just been sold in the new Alden Terrace Homes development near 241st Street and Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, L.I., Phoebus Kaplan, president, reported yesterday.

Despite the threat of war, the high rate of building activity in Rome, Italy, has been maintained thus far, with many new and modern sections being developed in that city, according to John C. Tysen, sales manager of Previews, Inc., who has just returned from a visit of nearly a month to many Italian cities.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 8--The political field has been stirred by the refusal of the Foreign Office to grant permission to return to Chile to Gustavo Ross, defeated Rightist candidate in the 1938 Presidential elections, who is now in New York. Senor Ross was Minister of Finance in President Arturo Alessandri's administration.

The Belt Parkway, a $34,000,000 express road running some thirty miles on the outskirts of Brooklyn and Queens from the Narrows to the Bronx Whitestone Bridge, was inspected in its entirety yesterday...

ELMIRA, N. Y., June 8 (UP)--The body of 7-year-old Thomas Lipnisky, Colebrook District School honor student, sought since Tuesday by more than 1,000 searchers, was found early today floating in Seeley Creek about a quarter mile below the pool where he was last seen wading with his father and cousin.
The United States and other neutral nations were warned yesterday that a Nazi victory in Europe might lead to inter-continental warfare, threatening democracy and Christianity throughout the world.

BOSTON, June 8--"Youth in itself holds no panacea for the ills of mankind," President Daniel L. Marsh told 1,458 graduating seniors of Boston University at the Boston Arena in his annual Baccalaureate sermon today.

More than fifty suites in the new eighteen-story apartment house at 875 Fiith Avenue, corner of Sixtyninth Street, being completed for occupancy in August, have been rented, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents for the structure.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, June 8 (AP)--The King and Queen informally visited the Canadian First Division for five hours today and saw every phase of its manoeuvres and routine work. They kept a promise they had made shortly after the Canadians reached England.

Angelo Trulio, New York State titleholder, and Henry Herz of the Bedford Y. M. C. A. gained the final of the invitation four-wall A. A. U. handball tournament at Ravenhall in Coney Island yesterday. Trulio defeated Sigmund Kulick, West Side Y. M. C. A., 21--13, 21--10, and Herz beat R. B. Turner, West Side Y. M. C. A., 19--21, 21--18, 21--16. The finalists will meet today.

YONKERS, N. Y., June 8--Edward L. Mathews, superintendent of way for the Third Avenue Railway Company, died at his home, 216 Lee Avenue, here, today at the age of 72.

ABOARD S.S. WASHINGTON, at Sea, Sunday, June 9 (AP)--This United States liner, with some 900 American refugees from Europe already aboard, was en route today from Le Verdon, France, to Lisbon, Portugal, to pick up more stranded Americans.

Discussing some of the probable effects of the war preparedness program in this country upon real estate, Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, says that industrial and commercial building will naturally expand.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 8-- Hungarian public opinion was aroused against the Nazis today because of a bill introduced in Parliament by Koloman Hubay, Hungarian Nazi leader, proposing that all minorities in Hungary receive full autonomy with the right to elect their ministers, local officials and judges.
The apartment house with stores on a 32-foot frontage at 565-67 Empire Boulevard in Brooklyn was sold by the John Pullman Real Estate Company, brokers, to Jane Seigel for investment.

BOSTON, June 8--John S. Young, director of radio and television at the World's Fair, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Science at the commencement exercises of Suffolk University next week. Mr. Young will be presented by Joseph E. Warner, former At torney General, who is a member of the board of trustees of Suffolk.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Miss Harriet Elliott, appointed to the National Defense Commission by President Roosevelt as the representative of consumers, promised the country's housewives today that food prices would be watched against undue rising and that standards of living would be protected during the emergency period.

PETIT GOAVE, Haiti--We were awakened before 7 by a sound that was almost but not quite a drum beat. The ship was without motion; this was Petit Goave. But why the drum sound so early on a Sunday morning? We rang for the steward.

ONE effect of the war on American philately has been to direct the attention of collectors in the United States toward the stamps of the Americas, particularly toward the postal paper of the Confederate States.
Large old-fashioned kitchens offer many possibilities for modernization, state FHA officials.
MOSCOW, June 8--Much space is devoted in the Soviet press today to reviews of the military situation developing in France, all of them thoroughly objective.

Flower arrangements this week in four of the refrigerated niches in the exhibition hall of Gardens on Parade at the World's Fair will he staged by members of member clubs of the Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut.

The indications were yesterday that the nation's greatest peacetime manoeuvres, which will involve 100,000 soldiers in the PlattsburgWatertown area of Northern New York in August will bear little resemblance to the swift, plunging blitzkrieg now going on in Europe.
Early in September there is to be held a conference on science, philosophy and religion in their relation to the democratic way of lift.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8Holy Cross made a clean sweep of its annual baseball series with Harvard today by scoring an 8-3 victory. It was the fourteenth straight victory of the season for the Crusaders.

Pan American Airways' Yankee Clipper, which returned to La Guardia Field after running into headwinds on its flight over the North Atlantic to Horta and Lisbon, took off again yesterday afternoon at 3:15 P.M.

The thesis requirement for graduation from the School of Business and Civic Administration at City College has been abolished for students completing their courses after Feb. 1, 1941, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nelson P. Mead, acting president.

Shoppers and shopkeepers and the public generally voiced their displeasure when some 600 members of the Trade Union Council to End Unemployment staged demonstrations yesterday morning in front of Republican National Headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street, and Democratic National Headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 8-A new method of mercerizing cotton fabrics so that the material not only has a high sheen and soft feel but is also practically shrinkproof, is offered in a patent (No. 2,203,375) awarded here to Ernst Weiss of Bunt, Wattwil, Switzerland.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 8 -This has been a jittery week in South America.
Miss Marie Bradford Fotterall Trench, daughter of Mrs. Stewart Potter Trench of 430 East Eighty-sixth Street, and of the late ...

NEWARK, N. J., June 9--With the arrest of five youths yesterday the police of this city claimed to have smashed a crime ring responsible for one murder, twenty-two hold-ups and eight burglaries. Four of the prisoners were seized after an automobile chase.
OTTAWA, June 8-Under pressure of events overseas, foreseen by no statesman on this side of the Atlantic or apparently over there either, Canada's war effort is being completely made over.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 8-- Mrs. Mary Reynolds Anstice, member of one of Rochester's oldest families, died today at the age of 84. She was the widow of Josiah Anstice, founder of the Anstice foundry, and was born in the Reynolds homestead, which her father, Mortimer F. Reynolds, gave to the city for a library.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., June 8-- The 108-acre estate formerly owned by Charles E. Mitchell, New York financier, was sold at auction today
Arthur M. Meeker of Westfield, N. J., has succeeded Guy D. Potter as commander of the Northern New Jersey Power Squadron. Eustace T. Ball has been named lieutenant commander, Henry A.

CLEVELAND, June 8 (AP)-The golfing professionals fire primarily for prestige, not for money, in the national open golf championship, but the 35 low scorers did split up $6,000 in the forty-fourth annual event which wound up in a tie today.

RENO, June 8 (AP)--Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan, tennis star, filed suit today to divorce Marshal Fabyan Jr. of Boston and Manchester, Mass. She charged cruelty and asked restoration of her maiden name, Sarah Palfrey. The marriage was Oct. 6, 1934.

YONKERS, N. Y., June 8--The Federal surplus commodity stamp plan will be put in effect here June 17 to increase by 50 per cent the purchasing power of 4,300 families on relief, according to an announcement today by Nicholas J. Ebbitt, Fublic Welfare Commissioner of the city.

DETROIT, June 8 (UP)--James F. Dewey, Federal Labor Conciliator, said today that negotiators had settled several important issues concerning a new contract between General Motors and the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers.

PARIS, June 8--French aviation replied today with reprisals in Berlin for the German air raid on Paris last Monday. A naval air squadron bombed industrial suburbs of Berlin, a communique of the French Air Ministry announced, adding that all the French planes returned to their base.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 8 (AP)--The Egyptian Government today suddenly sent 6,000 children and aged men and women from Alexandria to the interior as all Italian ships in the Mediterranean were reported to have received orders to return immediately to Italy.

Today will be the last advantageous time to see the iris display at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park, officials of the institution said yesterday. Six thousand iris plants are in full bloom in the garden's collection. Rhododendrons are another feature for this week-end, it was said.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 8-Dan Carmichael of Princeton beat Ted Harrison of Yale in a pitchers' duel on University Field today as the Tigers triumphed over their Blue rivals, 2-0, before an Alumni Day crowd of 8,000.
BOSTON, June 8--Tall Johnny Gorsica chalked up his first major league victory today as his Tiger team-mates thumped the Red Sox for the second successive day, 4-2. The Red Sox still clung to the top

ALBANY, June 8 (AP)--Two thousand truckmen of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauf feurs, Stablemen and Helpers went on strike in Eastern New York today after, a union official said, employers refused to grant a fiftyhour week and a week's vacation with pay.
The small seaport of Galway, on Ireland's western shore, accustomed chiefly to battered fishing boats with their catches of mackerel and herring, played host last week to a transatlantic liner.

According to radio reports received, yesterday by the United States Lines from the President Roosevelt, which is bringing 710 American refugees from Galway, Ireland, the ship will dock at 9 o'clock tonight at Pier 59, North River and Eighteenth Street.

READING, Mass., June 8--The marriage of Mrs. Mary Adden White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard P. Adden of this place, to Francis Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Brown of Amherst, Mass., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 284 Summer Avenue.

LONDON, June 8--The ship Carinthia, one of Cunard's best intermediate liners, put into operation as an armed merchant cruiser, has been sunk by a submarine, the Admiralty announced today. Two officers and two sailors were lost.

Berkeley C. Sexton, 58 years old, of 4 East Sixty-fourth Street, committed suicide by poison in a ninth floor room at the Hotel Plaza, it became known yesterday morning when a friend rushed in to inform the manager of a letter from Mr. Sexton announcing his intention to kill himself.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., June 8 (AP) -Ellison (Tarzan) Brown of Westerly won the New England A.A.U. 20-kilometer-championship run today, after a duel with Johnny Kelley of Medford, Mass., and Leslie Pawson of Pawtucket. The Indian led most of the way, and was timed

Sitting around a horseshoe desk in a high-ceilinged Washington hearing room, members of the House Military Affairs Committee listened last week to the testimony of General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army.

SAN FRANCISCO. SOME smart lad connected with the press department of the Golden Gate International Exposition has had cards printed to exhort to decorum the visitors to press headquarters on Treasure Island.
PARIS, June 8--"Our gunners are becoming expert in tackling German tanks. One battery of 75's bagged no fewer than twenty-five yesterday."
Today completes one month from the day on which the Nazis launched their simultaneous invasion of Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 8--Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Hawes of this place gave a garden party at their place here today to aid the Red Cross War Relief Fund. The hostess was assisted by her sister-in-law, Mrs. Kenneth Matthews of London.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 8 (AP)Joey Fishbach of New York, former national junior champion, defeated Billy Talbert of Cincinnati today in the New England tennis tournament and earned the right to meet Ladislav Hecht, Czecho-Slovak...

The question of including a dining room in the average home continues to be, it is pointed out, a matter of various interpretations. There seems, however, a general agreement that a separate dining room used for no other purpose is hardly justified in the modern small home.
With steadiness in Bombay and less hedging pressure than for several days, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved up 5 to 8 points yesterday and closed at the best levels of the session.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 8 --Lawrence G. Gillan was elected president of the Rutgers University alumni association at the 109th annual meeting of the organization on the university campus today. Gillan, a resident of Metuchen, was a member of the class of 1915 and succeeds Paul D. Prentiss, '14, of Westfield.

Dr. R. McKenzie Brown of Los Angeles was elected president of the American Laryngological, Rhinological and Otologlcal Society at the final session yesterday of the society's forty-sixth annual convention in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 8 (AP)--Dr. Hugh Dalton, Minister of Economic Warfare, told the British people in a broadcast tonight that "streaks of shortage are spreading like wales (welts) across the economic body of Germany."

A new group of brick dwellings will be opened today by the Bronx Housing Corporation at Bailey Avenue, near West 238th Street at the south end of Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. According to Edwin H. Wolf, president of the building firm, the homes contain seven rooms, are fully insulated and have finished basement recreation rooms.
Formation of a Business and Professional Women's Committee of the United Republican Finance Committee under the leadership of Miss Amy Lorton was announced...

BUTLER,, Pa., June 8 (AP)--Wallace Barker, vice president for operations of the Pullman Standard Car Corporation's plant here, said today the company had accepted a $3,000,000 order for shells from the Allied purchasing commission.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 8-- Roger Phelps Clark, District Attorney of Broome County, 1901 to 1910, and for ten years counsel to former Governors Charles Evans Hughes and Horace White, died...

CHICAGO, June 8-The United States District Court here was asked today to reject the current plan for reorganization of the Chicago North Western Railway and to refer the entire subject back to the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington for further action.

MANILA, June 8 (AP)--The engagement of Miss Ann Smeallie, daughter of Rear Admiral John M. Smeallie, to Flying Lieutenant Jesse Beverly Burks, U.S.N., of Dothan, Ala., was announced today. The wedding is planned for August. Admiral Smeallie is commandant of the Sixteenth United States Naval District with headquarters at Cavite, P.I.
A "World's Fair of Medicine," displaying the promise of new conquests of disease and better health for the world of tomorrow, will...

BERLIN, June 8 (UP)--King Leopold, who surrendered his Belgian Army to the Germans, has asked the International Red Cross to take charge of his three children, now living in France, a usually reliable informant said today.

Every person living in the United States today who is not a citizen of this country should be required to register with the government, according to overwhelming sentiment revealed in a nation-wide survey by the institute.

SACRAMENTO, June 8 (AP)--Ambrose O'Connell of New York, second assistant postmaster general, was removed to a hospital today after a heart attack. A physician reported he was "resting comfortably." Mr. O'Connell, on a speaking tour of West Coast postmasters' conventions, was stricken en route to Reno.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 8 (AP)-- Secretary of State Hull, who has several times disclaimed interest in running for the Presidency, declared in a letter made public today he considers himself "out of politics."

Terming the battle of the Somme "America's battle just as much as it is the Allies," Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, declared yesterday that the United States has fallen "far short of providing the full aid" necessary to bring victory to the Allies.

ROME, June 8-On Wednesday evening the Italian Government announced what had been an open secret in well-informed circles: the coast has been mined and henceforth ships come inside the twelvemile limit at their peril, if they do so without authorization and official escort.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8-- Mrs. Felix M. Warburg of Woodlands, this place, will entertain the officers and members of the committee for the Westchester fete, sponsored by the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, on Monday.

LONDON, June 8 (AP)--Michael Scott, British amateur golf champion in 1933 and captain of the Walker Cup team in 1934, married today Marie Martinella. The bridegroom is the youngest son of the late third Earl of Eldon.

Milton Males and James D'Agostino, builders at Wheeler Avenue and Eastern Boulevard, Bronx, report that their second unit of homes has been entirely sold. A new model home has been opened in the third group. The homes are two blocks from the new Soundview City Park.

Before painting moss--covered brick or stone, wash with water to which has been added 2 per cent of carbolic acid and follow with an application of plain water with a stiff brush. The growth should come off easily under this treatment.

LENOX, Mass., June 8--Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, motored to Lenox from Hyde Park this afternoon and awarded prizes at the Fox Hollow School Horse Show given by Miss Aileen M. Farrell, head mistress, ...
HAVANA, June 8--At 8 A. M., after an all-night session, the Constituent Assembly completed the new Cuban Constitution, which will go into effect Sept. 15.
Growing interest in the subject of low-rent housing throughout the nation is leading to the establishment of an increasing number of courses and study classes in this field.

The S.S. Kresge Company leased for a long term a store in the Cord Meyer Building on Continental Avenue near Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. The space ie 8,000 Square feet. The store ie being altered and air-conditioning equipment is being installed. The work le being supervised by Theobold H. Englehardt, Forest Hills architect. Robert E. Fausel of Manhattan acted as broker in the lease.

Members of society and devotees of racing from many parts of the East and South forsook all other forms of entertainment offered yesterday to attend the final program of the twenty-four day meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park and to see the running of the Belmont Stakes, closing day feature for 3-year-olds.

Initial Fall activity in the better dress field will get under way this week when a number of producers, including the members of the Sportswear Guild and a group of firms featuring costume ensembles, will present their new lines.
The American Export liner Exeter sailed from Jersey City at 12:20 P. M. yesterday for Genoa, Piraeus, Alexandria and Haifa, Palestine.

A new threat arose to plague the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium, a gangling giant from the sandlots of Cleveland with a lazy, bewildering pitching style and a fast ball that sweeps past hitters like a slug out of a Mauser.

WASHINGTON, June 8-A sizable group of men and women representing a nation-wide cross-section of the Republican party will gather in Philadelphia on June 19 to undertake one of the most difficult tasks in the history of American politics, the framing of the Republican platform for this year's campaign.

FREEPORT, June 8--Three thousand children took part today in the annual Sunday school parades in Freeport and Valley Stream. Receptions were held later on the lawns of the churches that participated. At Freeport, Mayor Robert E. Patterson and members of the Village Board of Trustees reviewed the marchers. William Moris was marshal of the parade.
ROME, June 8--The possibility of United States intervention on the side of the Allies is today in the forefront of Italian comments and thoughts.

The stock market resumed yesterday the creeping advance on persistently light dealings that has characterized it so far this month.
New exhibitions organized as benefits for various war relief funds continue to put in an appearance. Several are scheduled to open today.

Three handicapped elementary school children is need of assistance were rewarded yesterday for their character, scholarship and health standards, when Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, awarded the M. Samuel Stern Memorial prizes of $200 each, together with certificates of merit.

It appears that the selling of British-owned United States corporate securities by the British Commission that was sent here for that purpose has fallen away to a mere trickle, especially since the German defeat of France.

The havoc wrought by war in Europe is responsible for bringing to Long Island one of the best polo matches the sport has seen in a good many years.

The second generation Japanese residents of the Hawaiian Islands are very loyal to the United States and would help this country in case of any trouble, Dr. Clarence Scott Anderson, Professor of Education at the Pennsylvania State College, said yesterday on his return from Honolulu, where he taught for thirteen months as an exchange professor.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25--Perplexing problems and difficult decisions are on the usual dockets of American political conventions.
BACK in December, 1939, one of Earl Long's supporters in Louisiana nearly laughed himself to death. "Of all the jackassery we have ever ...

STOCKHOLM Sweden, June 25-- The war on the European Continent is finished, and now starts the war on the four continents against Europe, with Britain as the last battering ram of democracy against the totalitarian powers. That is the analysis of Swedish press opinion on the world situation following the French acceptance of the German-Italian armistice terms.

The Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the A.F. of L. parent of the performer unions, faces a severe financial crisis as a result of its prolonged war with the stagehands last Summer, it be came known yesterday.
ROME, June 25 (AP)--Her fortnight of war against France victoriously ended, Italy rallied forces tonight for a supreme effort to crush Great Britain's influence in the Mediterranean.

Sixty manufacturers, comprising the membership of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, have entered into an agreement banning advertising subsidies, in order to conform with the Robinson-Patman Act and the regulations of the Federal Trade Commission, it was learned here yesterday. These producers do about 80 to 85 per cent of the annual blouse volume of about $26,000,000.
BERLIN, June 25--With France beaten, the German press today posed the question: What is the next step? It did not, however, have to seek far for an answer.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 25--Military authorities say stories that both entrances to the Panama Canal have been mined by the Navy are greatly exaggerated. Your correspondent has just visited three military reservations, including Fort Amador, without challenge, and there was nothing to indicate that they had been put on a war footing.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)--The nation shouldered today its heaviest Federal tax load since the World War.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25-- Frank Borzage was named today by Metro to direct "Flight Command" with Robert Taylor, which is scheduled to go before the cameras late in July.

ROME, June 25--Italy gained military occupation of only a slim border belt in the Alps, demilitarization of French colonial outposts in North Africa and full rights over Jibuti, the only rail outlet to Italian East Africa, under terms of the French-Italian armistice announced here tonight.
The Tricolor hung limply at halfstaff outside the French Pavilion at the World's Fair yesterday, in solemn observance of the national day of mourning proclaimed by the conquered homeland.
The "bomb" found in a Pullman car arriving from Washington Monday night in Pennsylvania Station proved yesterday to be a forgotten sample of a munitions salesman.
ABOARD THE ALASKA CLIPPER, June 25--Alaska moved three days closer or within six hours of the United States today.

PITTSBURGH, June 25--John S. Fisher, former Governor of Pennsylvania, died at his home here today after a long illness. He had been confined to his apartment since undergoing an operation in September. He was 73 years old.

LONDON, June 25--The slump in home industrials was halted in the stock markets today although the section remained unsettled. The severe overnight fall was sufficient to check any fresh attempt at selling, and in addition there was a growing feeling that the marking down of shares had been overdone in many cases.

Leonard Nugent, 21 years old, was convicted speedily of first-degree murder in General Sessions yesterday. He was on trial accused of the fatal shooting of Isidore Cohen, 42, a war veteran and button merchant, during a hold-up on Aug. 4 ...

In an interview heard and seen here yesterday by television from the Municipal Auditorium in Philadelphia, the consensus of six newspaper men was that deals were under way for the votes of large unpledged delegations and that a break might be expected any time after the third ballot.

MILWAUKEE, June 25 (AP)--Miss Ellamae Williams of Chicago fought a soggy turf and a strong northeast wind at the Blue Mound Country Club today to score a 78, three over par, and win medalist honors in the qualifying round of the women's western open golf championship.
LONDON, June 25--Great Britain moved today to give her proconsuls in India and Burma full authority to govern the country without reference to the central authority.
A rain of mud descended upon Times Square for about ten minutes last night as a dust storm swirled through Manhattan and up into Westchester.

In a cablegram to the British Government yesterday a group of French citizens living in the United States expressed their belief that the present administration of France, because of the German occupation, was no longer in a position to safeguard French interests abroad.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 25 (AP)-- Kuno, last year's 2-year-old champion and Winter favorite to win the rich Hambletonian Stake for trotters at Goshen, N.Y., on Aug. 14, went down to defeat today in the $5,725 champion stallion stake of the Grand Circuit harness racing program at the Indiana State Fairgrounds.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25--Official and unofficial women Republicans divided themselves today into two divergent groups, on the second day of the national convention.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 25 --The Garden Club Federation of Massachusetts, Mrs. Henry Howe Richards of Groton, president, held a dinner here tonight at Red Lion Inn.

Mrs. Lowry Gillett of 133 East Seventy-third Street and Syosset, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Enid Gillett, to Peter Irving Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Irving of 65 East Ninety-sixth Street.

MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, Philadelphia, June 25--The Republican party finally found its lungs tonight for Herbert Hoover, its living reminder of the vanished days when the White House was under different management.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25-- The landing of the first settlers was enacted today at Tod's Point, Old Greenwich, as part of the tercentenary celebration. Many spectators gathered at the shore front where Captain Robert Feaks and his partner, Captain Daniel Patrick arrived in July, 1640.

Arthur B. Purvis, director-general of the British Purchasing Commission in the United States, stated yesterday that on June 17 "all existing contracts for war materials entered into by the French Government with American suppliers were assigned to the British Government."

OMAHA, June 25--Army officials of the Seventh Corps Area, with the cooperation of the Union Pacific Railroad, experimented successfully this morning with an airplane reporting system such as might be put into effect to warn of the approach of hostile planes in time of war.

BERLIN, June 26--Currency in the "new Europe," envisaged by the Germans following a victorious conclusion of the war, is to be based, as in the Reich, on the "productive achievements of labor." This is the opinion voiced tonight by the organ of the Ruhr industrialists, Deutsche Bergwerkszeitung.

TRENTON, June 25--Bills prohibiting children under 12 years of age from working, requiring children under 16 to attend school and prescribing the types of work that may be performed by those between the ages of 12 and 18 became law today when Governor Moore signed them in the presence of a large group of interested persons.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 25 (AP)--Dr. Louis H. Dodson, physician for the New Jersey State Boxing Commission, today pronounced Tony Galento "very fit" for his fifteenround heavyweight battle in Jersey City next Tuesday against Max Baer.

Can any statistician or sociologist tell or guess how many misers to the hundred thousand there are in this town? Almost every week one or two are discovered. Usually only death brings them to notice.

Miss Phyllis Harriman Russell, a granddaughter of Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, United States Minister to Norway, was married to John Hartley Lewis, son of Arthur Lewis and of Mrs. Hilton Lewis of Medfield, Mass., yesterday afternoon here in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. The rector, the Rev. John W. Suter Jr., performed the ceremony.
An unusually firm market for the pound sterling, together with moderately active trading, was the feature yesterday in foreign exchange.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 25 (AP)-- Loomis School's crew took the lead in preliminary races for the Mallory Cup in the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association's eleventh annual regatta at the Naval Academy today.

Arthur R. Freedlander, portrait painter and art teacher, and brother of Joseph H. Freedlander, the architect, died on Monday in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken residential space in apartment buildings throughout the city was Robert Cresswell, treasurer of The New York Herald Tribune, who leased a garden suite in 31 East Sixty-third Street through Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., brokers.

For the first time in the sixtyfive-year history of New York's Floating Hospital it will be possible this Summer for children who are ill to make daily trips on the boat until their convalescence is complete.

The report of the Collins Aikman Corporation, textile manufacturers, and subsidiaries, excluding the Canadian subsidiary, announced yesterday, reveals a net profit of $741,085 for the quarter ended on June 1, after deductions for depreciation, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.

The board of directors of the National Consumers League yesterday addressed a letter to President Roosevelt asking him to issue a public proclamation to the effect that he will, in this period of emergency, seek to preserve labor standards and social services.

In its second day the Philadelphia convention continued to be engagingly human, despite the serious undercurrents. There were speakers who, as their friends testified, did not mince words--not even little words that no one would miss.

Space has been leased in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which will establish there a World's Fair information bureau for its dealers and customers. The company maintained a similar office in Rockefeller Center last year. Howard Wills will be in charge.

Communications facilities between France and the United States were reduced sharply yesterday when service was halted on the two direct radio circuits linking New York and Bordeaux. The breach is believed to result from Germany's peace terms, which stipulate that all wireless transmitting stations in French territory must cease operations.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 26-- Great Britain is obviously carrying out its threat to trade bomb for bomb with the German Air Force.

A further drop of half a point in the general death rate for New York City for the week ending last Saturday was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Health Department.

The decision of George L. Harrison to remain president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank during the rest of the year, instead of leaving that office on July 1 to become president of the New York Life, is highly gratifying news.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25--A last-minute thrust of Eastern and Western foes of intervention today converted the Republican platform plank on foreign policy into a stronger declaration for keeping the United States out of foreign wars and protecting this hemisphere against attacks from abroad than had been intended.

LONDON, June 25--Several thousand Polish soldiers, members of the Polish Legion formed in France with the determination to continue fighting after their homeland was overrun by the Germans have arrived in Britain safely and their intention to participate in the defense of Britain, or any other ...

OTTAWA, June 25--A "terrific" demand for the new dollar passports permitting Canadians to visit the United States during the next year is reported by the External Affairs Department. Literally thousands of applications are pouring in and there is difficulty in providing sufficient application blanks.

LONDON, June 25 (UP)--Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Premier of conquered France, said tonight that the French armies and fleet must be disarmed but that his government "remains free and our honor is safe."

DETROIT, June 25--A broad program for the strengthening of the Democratic system in the United States was urged by Rabbi Max Arzt, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, at the opening session of the annual convention today.
The whereabouts and the eventual disposition of the French Navy continued yesterday to be the most important topic of the war.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP)-- Johnny Rizzo blasted a three-run homer today against his former mates from Pittsburgh, but the Phillies never quite caught up and lost the opening game of a series, 9--7.

A private dwelling on East Seventy-fourth Street near Fifth Avenue and a tenement on Second Avenue near the approach to the Queens Midtown Tunnel, both of which had been held by the families of the sellers for many years, passed into new ownership yesterday.

Although producers have found costs rising because of the difficulty of importing carpet wools, advances in list prices at the openings of floor covering lines next Monday are not likely to occur, according to trade reports yesterday. It was believed that manufacturers would seek to edge prices upward during the season, and market talk at the openings will be directed toward that objective.
Twelve "Cinderella girls" arrived in New York yesterday with prospects for fun and frivolity more than equaling those of the storied lady for whom they are named.

LONDON, June 25--The government has not made any arrangements whereby people here will be allowed to send their children to the British dominions and the United States and remit the cost of their upkeep, Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 25--The premises of the Merion Cricket Club were thronged with restive college tennis players today, irked by the second postponement of the start of the national intercollegiate championships.
ORANGE, N.J., June 25--Highseeded players swung into action in the New Jersey State tennis championships at the Berkeley Tennis Club today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 25--Governor Lehman urged today intensification of public health work against tuberculosis and venereal diseases which might hamper the national defense and accompanying industrial program.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 25-- With the exception of Mrs. Mortimer May of Inwood, a former New York State titleholder, who lost to Mrs. Joseph C. Dey Jr. of the home club, 1 down, all the favorites advanced to the second round of the women's Long Island match-play championship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

MEXICO CITY, June 25--The body of Robert Sheldon Harte of New York, Leon Trotsky's guard, who disappeared after an attack on the Russian exile's house on May 24, was discovered last night buried under the floor of a farmhouse kitchen about twenty miles from Mexico City.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 25-- What the insurance industry once regarded as its greatest difficulty has become a major asset because of the war, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of the New York Insurance Department, said today to members of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners here, declaring that insurance faced the future "with unusual cash resources sufficient to meet any reasonable stress and strain."

CLEVELAND, June 25--The Yankees struggled valiantly through sunshine and showers today in a desperate effort to turn a powerful tide that seems determined to sweep a once great champion ball club into total oblivion.
PARIS, June 25 (via Berlin)-- Roger Langeron, Police Prefect since 1934, has been dismissed by General Alfred von Vollard-Bockelberg, German Military Governor of the Paris region.

The marriage of Miss Adaline Ida Heffelfinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ellwood Heffelfinger of New York, to Richard Taylor Gore of Ithaca, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Charles Gore, took place here last night in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George E. Rath, assistant chaplain of Columbia University.

Emphasizing that America had been warned in time, Miss Fannie Hurst, addressing 400 members of the National Council of Jewish Women and the National Council of Jewish Juniors at the World's Fair yesterday, urged a temporary "detour" away from our normal national ideals in the interest of a quickened preparation for defense.

Free lighterage in the Port of New York was described as "a racket" yesterday by Milton P. Bauman, New Jersey attorney, at the Interstate Commerce Commission hearing of the New Jersey lighterage case in the Hotel St. George.

WASHINGTON, June 25--A program for voluntary training of 5,000 young men aged 19 to 26 each year as officers in the naval reserve to man the expanded fleet was announced today by President Roosevelt after a conference with naval officials.

WASHINGTON, June 25--The whereabouts of the American fleet remained a mystery tonight, although reports persisted that it was heading for the Panama Canal and the Atlantic. Other guesses were that the fleet was heading toward the Far East.

MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 25--In a speech tonight attacking the New Deal as leading to the same suicide road that brought disaster in Europe as well as failing to revive industry and diminish unemployment, Herbert Hoover, former President of the United States, virtually challenged the delegates to the Republican National Convention to nominate him for President if they had the courage to make a real fight at the election in November.

MADRID, June 25--Rested and at ease in the British Embassy here the Duke and Duchess of Windsor told this morning how they fled from France with only sardines to eat during the long drive from Cap d'Antibes on the Spanish frontier.

Ruling that the City Administration had full control over Municipal Court salaries, Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter yesterday dismissed an action brought by Lewis A. Abrams and fifty-two other Municipal Court justices to void pay cuts imposed on them since July 1, 1937, and to recover ...

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,846,450 barrels, an increase of 30,250 over the 3,816,200 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 26-- Early this morning the British Government issued a statement declaring that if the French Empire abided by the terms of the ItaloGerman armistice "it will be parceled out between Germany and Italy, and France herself will be permanently reduced to the condition of a vassal State."

Members of the New York Stock Exchange Golf Association assembled for their forty-fourth annual tournament under clearing skies at the Glen Oaks Club, Great Neck, L.I., yesterday, 128 members participating in the sport and some 200 attending the dinner that followed.
With additions by mail from upState New York, New Jersey and Delaware, the applications for the 1940 Plattsburg Camp passed a total of 2,100 yesterday for 500 vacancies.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25--Delegates do not seem to notice it, but radio men and motion picture crews are locked in grim and silent war on the floor of the convention hall. It is the Battle of the Sign.

WASHINGTON, June 25--Germany has an agreement with the Soviet Union under which the Russians will be permitted to take over Bessarabia and the Reich is urging the recently reconstituted Rumanian Government to concede this territory without fighting, it was reported in well-informed diplomatic circles here today.

NOROTON, Conn., June 25--Mrs. James M. Robbins of Lawrence Farms, medalist in the eighteenth annual championship of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association, won from Mrs. H.W. Herrick of Bonnie Briar, 1 up, in the first round of match play at Wee Burn today.

BOSTON, June 25--Somewhere down this side of Nantucket Lightship sixteen of the yachts that started oft Block Island yesterday in the Cruising Club's ocean race up and down the coast were believed tonight to be making slow progress toward Mount Desert Rock, near Bar Harbor, Me., their second objective before the finish at Gloucester.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25-- Charles Davis of Lawrenceville and Benno Janssen of Exeter tied for the lead with 76s in the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the twenty-ninth annual Eastern interscholastic golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Grant Simmons gave a supper dance here tonight at their home on Clapboard Ridge to introduce their daughter, Miss Frances Ethridge Simmons.
Oscar Schaefer, who trolls off the beach in a Gibb skiff not much longer than a boat rod, reports that there are more striped bass off Deal, N.J., than he has ever seen at one time.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 25--I have just spent a fortnight in Brazil, from which strict censorship prohibits the transmission of fifth-column news. Therefore I have come here to write.

When Mayor La Guardia opens the new Belt Highway next Saturday the whole eastern flank of New York City will be circled by thirty-three miles of the finest motor drive in the country. One short link through Coney Island remains unfinished.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP)--Mrs. Emil Denemark's Madison and Rene A. Coward's Gold Mesh won the cofeatures at Suffolk Downs today, Madison romping home by five lengths and Gold Mesh scoring by four. Both races were claiming sprints for $1,650-$1,250 platers and were contested over a sloppy track amidst showers.

CHICAGO, June 25--The Chicago North Western Railroad began today the presentation of evidence in opposition to the plan of the Interstate Commerce Commission for reorganization of the road at hearings before Federal Judge Barnes here.
The campaign in France, after a duration of only six weeks, has ended with an incomparable victory for German arms. There has been an armistice since 1:35 A.M. today.

Despite the assurances of Chairman Hyde that there has been "no controversy" in his committee, it is evident that the makers of the 1940 Republican platform have had difficulty in agreeing on a plank on foreign affairs.

Sent into overtime by a ninth-inning homer by Babe Phelps, the Dodgers finally succumbed to the Cubs in the thirteenth under the lights at Ebbets Field last night. Pushing five runs across the plate in the fourth extra stanza, the Chicagoans earned an 8--3 victory in the nocturnal thriller, which lasted 3 hours and 29 minutes.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $6,325,010, compared with a net of $4,612,118 in the twelve months to April 30, 1939, or a gain of $1,712,892. Gross revenues of the system for the period were $112,448,765, against $104,639,871 previously.

The Greater New York Women's Committee of the Queen Wilhelmina Fund, Inc., has raised $61,131 in the four weeks its campaign has been in operation, Mrs. Edgar Leonard, chairman, announced yesterday at her weekly meeting with volunteer workers at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Mrs. Leonard said $11,739 collected last week brought the fund's grand total to $164,883. The committee is seeking to raise $300,000 as its quota of a nationwide total of $3,000,000.

The marriage of Miss Alison Treat Bruere, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Henry Bruere, to George Carnahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Holmes Carnahan of New York and Torreon, Mexico, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 925 Park Avenue.

TRENTON, June 25--The Legislature recessed shortly before dawn today until next Monday night after electing in joint session new superintendents of elections in Hudson and Essex Counties and then abolishing the positions of Commissioner of Registration in those counties.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange declined more than $1 a bale yesterday as the result of commissionhouse liquidation of a line of October contracts purchased last week. Although the recession stimulated covering operations, the list ended 19 to 25 points lower than on Monday.

The New York Clearing House Committee at a meeting yesterday decided to recommend to the full meeting of the Clearing House membership on Friday that the banks forego the planned Summer Saturday closings.

Eligibility requirements for New York City public school licenses, covering teaching and supervisory staffs, have been extensively revised by a special committee of educators and are now before the Board of Education for approval, it was announced yesterday.
The Duchess of Leeds has left the Waldorf-Astoria to vist her sister, Mrs. Edward L. Jones in Philadelphia.
The stock market declined steadily yesterday in slightly heavier trading, led by industrial shares, losing much of last week's slow gains and closing at the lowest level since June 13.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25-- Two debutante parties that were to have taken place this evening to complete the calendar of a week of dinners and dances for the young women who are being introduced this season on Long Island were canceled because of the war.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, June 25 (AP)--United States diplomats arranged today for the removal of 300 more Americans from France.

MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, Philadelphia, June 25--A capacity crowd of 17,000 persons keyed to a high pitch of expectancy for a scheduled speech by former President Hoover filled this auditorium tonight for the night session of the second day of the Republican National Convention.

The first cross-Manhattan express highway, the new tunnel extending from the west side of Manhattan at the George Washington Bridge to the east side at Highbridge Park, at Amsterdam Avenue will be opened to public traffic tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 25--An announcement made jointly tonight by the Treasury and Navy Departments showed that the United States had employed one of its warships, the cruiser Vincennes, to assist in removing French gold that might have been seized by Nazi invaders.
DETROIT, June 25--The Tigers kept their hold on second place in the tight American League race today by splitting a double bill with the Red Sox before a crowd of 26,169.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25--Harassed "leading candidates" for the Republican Presidential nomination redoubled their efforts to glean convention votes today, in the face of the threat of a new active contender in the person of former President Herbert Hoover.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 25--Premier Reflik Saydam is expected to make his long-awaited declaration of Turkish foreign policy in Parliament tomorrow. Numan Menemencioglu, Secretary General of the Foreign Ministry, returned today before the end of his vacation, presumably to he present for the statement.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which handles the bulk of the applications for releases from "frozen" foreign funds in the United States before these requests are passed on to the United States Treasury for rulings, reported yesterday a record day, with applications approximating 700.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 25 --A Cabinet crisis has been produced by the Congressional investigation of the Nazi plot to seize Uruguay as a German colony.

WASHINGTON, June 25--Relations between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the investment industry took a significant turn today when it was learned that the SEC was preparing to ask Congress soon for authority to waive the obnoxious twenty-day waiting period under the Securities Act.

DETROIT, June 25--Richard W. Reading, former Mayor of Detroit, was held for trial today at the conclusion of his examination on charges of graft growing out of the current one-man grand jury investigation by Circuit Judge Homer Ferguson.

Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday asking the public to join in the observance of National Sports Week during the first seven days of July.
A.E. Forster, with Hercules Powder Company since 1925, has been appointed assistant general manager of the company's naval stores department.

Eli L. Oliver, who quit as executive vice president of Labor's Nonpartisan League in protest against the anti-Roosevelt stand of its chairman, John L. Lewis, has received the offer of Alex Rose's post as State executive secretary of the American Labor party, it became known last night.

With seven 3-year-olds, including the Belair Stud's Fenelon, named for the Irvington Purse, Empire City will begin its Summer race meeting today at the old Yonkers course which began as a trotting track. Now, with $600,000 in improvements and alterations spent on it, ...

Conducting his first Sunday service as dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Very Rev. Dr. James P. DeWolfe yesterday emphasized his belief that the Christian faith would ultimately triumph over "materialistic concepts which have filled the world with discouragement and despair."

New York University has leased the four-story residence at 5 Washington Square North, it was announced yesterday by Dr. LeRoy E. Kimball, school controller. Ths property, one of the famous redbrick structures constituting "The Row" at Washington Square, is owned by Sailors Snug Harbor and has been leased for a long term.

WASHINGTON, June 30--A summary of apppropriations available to the Department of Agriculture for the fiscal year 1941, beginning on July 1, indicates that appropriations from all sources amount to $1,195,523,918, a decrease of $303,801,663 from the total of $1,499,325,581 available for the 1940 fiscal year.

Although they have no intention of switching media, many national advertisers have become seriously concerned because they "have put all their eggs in one basket" by concentrating so large a proportion of their advertising budgets in radio, several of them admitted yesterday.

Demand for Summer merchandise showed a general decline in the wholesale markets last week, but interest in Fall goods was more active. There was considerable demand for costume suits in fur-trimmed and untrimmed versions, with sports types selling for back-to-college promotions.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP)--The Cardinals and Pirates exchanged shut-outs before a crowd of 25,096 in two games twice halted by light showers today. St. Louis won the opener 1--0, and the Pirates the nightcap, 2--0.

THIS morning, at the risk of prolonging the here-are-the-good-books-of-the-season-don't miss-them business to painful lengths, I follow Mr. Poore's round-up of last Friday and Saturday with a list of my own. The period covered is six months (Jan. 1-July 1) rather than the usual four, but the order of listing is, as usual, haphazard.

The annual exodus of thousands of boy and girl campers was in full swing yesterday. The movement is expected to reach its peak today, and transportation lines hope to deliver most of the campers to their rustic quarters before the beginning of the great annual Fourth of July week-end rush.

The Allied Relief Fund, organized recently to combine the efforts of various relief agencies throughout the United States, will begin Thursday a campaign for $5,000,000 to provide shelter in this country for European children who are now ...

Dissatisfied with the progress of negotiations for a new contract covering 35,000 coat and suit workers in the metropolitan district, the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F.L., served notice on four manufacturers' associations yesterday that it would consider strike action if no agreement were reached by next Saturday.

A former patrolman, who eight years ago forsook the city's crowded streets for the cloistered quiet of the seminary, yesterday came to the climax of his years of study and devotion by celebrating his first solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral before 3,500 of his uniformed former colleagues and high ...

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 30-- Ocean Beach Park, New London's $3,000,000 recreational development on the site of the resort razed by the hurricane of 1938, was opened today at exercises attended by Governor Raymond E. Baldwin and Senator Francis T. Maloney. Thousands of persons thronged to the shore to witness the dedication of the fifty-acre tract along the halfmile crescent of beach.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30--Having polished off the two Phillie aces, Hughie Mulcahy and Kirby Higbe, in the first two games of the series, the Giants expected to have some brisk batting practice in a double-header before 10,816 fans at Shibe Park today. But they certainly took a long time getting around to it.

Arms-making on the scale demanded by the new United States defense program provides a task which is "almost inconceivably complex," according to the monthly letter of the National City Bank of New York. It points out the statement of C.F. Kettering of the General Motors Corporation that even in the automobile industry preparations for new models must begin more than a year in advance.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 30--In the unseasonal chill of early evening Frank Guernsey of Rice Institute walked off the grandstand court of the Merion Cricket Club in defeat today, his two-year reign as national intercollegiate tennis champion at an end.

WASHINGTON, June 30--Establishment of a Joint Congressional Appropriations Committee provided with a permanent staff of specialists on budgetary and financial problems was recommended today by the Brookings Institution as a means of promoting "judicious determination of financing policy," as against the present usual method of compromise on appropriation policy ...

All the misery wrought in this world by sickness and sin combined does not equal that brought on by fear and anxiety, the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of the South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 30 --Two trainloads of wounded soldiers from Bessarabia and Bukovina, which arrived in Bucharest today, confirmed reports that have reached the capital that there had been clashes between the Russian and Rumanian troops in those provinces. It is said that many others have been killed but it is impossible to estimate the number.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 30-- Stewart Iglehart and Cecil Smith, ten-goal players who will captain the teams in the Red Cross benefit match on July 14, came together on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club today, Great Neck, led by Iglehart, scored a surprising 10-to-5 victory over Texas.

Oscar W. Swift, lawyer and former member of the House of Representatives, died early yesterday morning, presumably of a heart attack, during his sleep at his home, 260 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. There had been no previous signs of illness. He was 71 years old.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 30-- Edwin R. Weeks, a well-known business man and civic leader here and former president of the National Music Dealers Association, was killed by a lightning bolt as he stood under an umbrella on the seventeenth hole of the Binghamton Country Club's golf course this afternoon. He was 72 years old.

PARIS, June 28 (Delayed; via Berlin)--Paris is adapting herself to new conditions with her usual grace. She emerges from the turmoil like a convalescent from a severe illness, pale and with diminished vigor, but still beautiful.

BERLIN, June 30--The railroad line to the southern Paris suburbs, Seine-et-Oise, via Massy, Palaiseau to Saint Remy en Chevreuse, is now open. Parisians today flocked out to see if their suburban homes were intact. Suburban dwellers who had remained at home came to Paris to buy food.

SCHULENBURG, Texas, June 30 --Flood waters born of week-end cloudbursts along the watersheds of the Colorado and Lavaca Rivers swept through the Southeast Texas area today, pouring into business districts of isolated towns and trapping many residents who took refuge in trees and on housetops.

An American flag was dedicated with prayer by the Rev. Arthur R. Kleps at the morning service yesterday at the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street, on the edge of Yorkville. The flag was presented to the church by Mrs. Helen A. Dieter.

ST. LOUIS, June 30--Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the pension plan which bears his name, declared today that he would "join hands with labor and form an entirely new political party," if Democrats and Republicans failed to enact legislation putting his proposal for a 2 per cent gross income tax into effect.

"If our nation thinks only of itself selfishly, isolation and immunization will lead to its end," the Rev. Dr. John C. Schroeder, Professor of Pastoral Theology at the Yale Divinity School, said yesterday in his sermon at the morning services of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

The Federal tax increase effective this morning will be reflected in the Amusement Area of the World's Fair, it became known yesterday, but it will not affect the admission price to the World of Tomorrow because the Fair is a non-profit, tax-exempt corporation.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP)--Senator Burton K. Wheeler declared tonight that a "new and great anti-war party" would be formed unless the Democratic party pledged not to send American soldiers "to a foreign shore."

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in June dropped to the smallest monthly volume since February and, for a corresponding month, to the lowest level in twenty years, with the exception of June, 1939. The largest day's business was 1,357,190 shares on June 12, and the dullest was 333,320 shares on June 21--the smallest turnover for a full day since last September.

If a survey of children's radio programs taken by the United Parents Associations of New York City is any indication, the sirenscreaming, gun-shooting gangster and "horror" radio dramas are looked upon with increasing disfavor by children, who are turning to programs of a more educational nature.

The full report of the Commerce Department on our foreign trade in May more than confirms the preliminary estimate. It shows that, although the Germans invaded Holland on May 10 and the Nazi forces broke through the French defense on the 15th, this country's export trade that month was in...
ROME, June 30--The Italian communique tonight reports "considerable activity" on the LibyanEgyptian frontier, where Italian troops are said to have repulsed attacks of British motorized columns.
It is becoming increasingly clear, in my opinion, that our interests as well as those of Britain lie in reaching a friendly understanding with Japan, if one can be attained.
WASHINGTON, June 30--Mr. and Mrs. American Consumer will get their first taste of the new defense taxes tomorrow.

Contradictory reports of Marshal Italo Balbo's death in Cyrenaica are bound to cause speculation. According to the first announcement from Rome, his plane, with nine others aboard, several of whom were noncombatants, crashed in flames after a battle with British aircraft over Tobruk. But the British Foreign Office explicitly denies ...

PARIS, June 28 (Delayed, via Berlin)--Today there is appreciation by the Frenchman in the street that a new government in a new France, under the auspices of a one-party government of a National Socialist flavor, is about to make its initial bow. Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, in his speech on June 25, said that a new order would be introduced, which was taken here ...
BERLIN, June 30--The second and "final" phase of the war in the West--the liquidation of Germany's war on Britain--is coming more actively within the range of German editorial speculation.

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week with the spot market steady in view of the limited supplies of "free" cotton in this country, while the futures market was depressed by the poor outlook for distribution of the staple occasioned by the European war.

It is already being hinted that Congress will be called upon to appropriate still more billions for national defense. War Department sources have indicated a wish for equipment costing $3,000,000,000 more than that already authorized, and in addition also, apparently, to the $4,000,000,000 already authorized by the House for a "two-ocean" navy.
A belt without a buckle is a poor thing, a fact Mayor La Guardia may have borne in mind during his relentless campaign for an RFC loan to finance the Battery-Brooklyn tunnel.

The early part of yesterday afternoon at Ebbets Field was highly enjoyable for 28,909 Flatbush fans because they saw the Dodgers beat the Bees, 9--2, and give Freddy Fitzsimmons his seventh triumph of the season and the 199th of his major league career.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 30--An appeal to the British Government to defend the Jewish Homeland and to help preserve democracy was made here today at the opening session of the Zionist Organization of America by Ludwig Lewisohn, honorary secretary.

The scream of the air raid sirens has now become a nightly alarm in many British factory towns. Every night, almost without intermission, waves of German bombers roar over British targets and drop their loads of death as far from the east coast as Wales and Southwestern England. Fortunately, the published figures of civilian casualties ...

WASHINGTON, June 30--Congress goes back to work tomorrow, after a recess over the Republican National Convention, with three important national defense measures up for consideration either before the two branches or their committees.
QUINCY, Ill., June 30 (AP)--Captain John E. Andrew, national commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, died here today in the Soldiers' and Sailors' Home Hospital, at the age of 91.

LONDON, Monday, July 1--British and German airmen exchanged bombs over the week-end, and once again London officials declared that the R.A.F. had inflicted great damage on numerous targets in Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Northern France, while the German air force was said to have accomplished little in its raids on this country.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 30-- Frank Aydelotte, American Secretary of Rhodes Scholarships, today sent an appeal to American Rhodes scholars throughout the country, asking their assistance in a plan to house in the United States for the duration of the war children of members of British universities. The children will come in under the English quota, which allows about 6,500 persons each month.

CHICAGO, June 30--The recent weather conditions have been favorable for the development of the corn crop, and the growth is about up to the seasonal normal in the big commercial producing areas. Good rains fell last week over a wide area, and while a period of ...

The twenty-four-foot auxiliary schooner Scarrlet II, owned and manned by Francis J. Scarr of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., son of the late head of the New York Weather Bureau, sank after a collision with an unidentified barge in the East River off Fifty-second Street at 1:30 A.M. yesterday. One of four boys who were making a week-end cruise with Mr. Scarr is missing.

BERLIN, June 30--Elimination of gold as the basis for European currencies and elevation of the Reichsmark to the rank of the standard currency for future continental economy--such is the ambitious plan fostered by the victorious termination of the war on the Continent, and gaining increased popularity not only among ...

Wendell L. Willkie, Republican Presidential nominee, returns to his office this morning at 20 Pine Street for a press conference and to wind up his affairs as president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, after having obtained a week-end of rest aboard Roy W. Howard's yacht.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 30-- One of the metropolitan district's foremost young riders, James A. Thomas Jr., added another link to his long chain of major victories today when he captured the horsemanship championship in the seventh annual Sands Point horse show held at the Luckenbach estate.

RED BANK, N.J., June 30--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt favors a plan of compulsory training in the interests of national defense for young men and women alike, she told members of the Monmouth County Women's Press Club in an interview staged in the home of Mrs. Lewis S. Thompson at Holmdel, near here.

Declaring that the war in Europe was a "Blitzkrieg against the spirit," United States Senator Claude Pepper of Florida said yesterday that civilization could not be saved by "spiritual midgets or moral isolationists," but only by "the stalwart, the steadfast, the brave."

A man described by the police as James Moore, between 27 and 30 years old, a postman living at 127 Sheldon Avenue, Tarrytown, N.Y., was killed about 2:30 A.M. yesterday when an automobile of which he was the owner and operator plunged into the East River from ...

IT'S a remarkable thing when a man comes to think about it, and Long George Kelly, coach of the Boston Bees, was the man who came to think about it. Long George, who was a big figure on first base for the Giants of other days, was taking his ease and recalling incidents of the rather wild time the Giants of 1924 had during their training stay in Sarasota.

BERLIN, June 30--Although during the first few days after signatures were affixed to the FrancoGerman armistice the security markets continued to sag, a manifestly firmer tendency developed late last week, with the result that, on balance, the stock price index registered a slight net gain.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 30--According to reliable reports, Bulgaria has assured Yugoslavia that she will not attack Rumania no matter what happens. At the same time a source close to King Boris told this correspondent that even if Hungary attempts forcibly to seize Transylvania Bulgaria will not move.
