CHICAGO, June 30--Wheat prices were on the down-grade last week, and the market is regarded as feeling the effect of the start of the after-harvest movement of the new crop in the Southwest, where the grain is commencing to arrive at interior terminals and Kansas City at a rate of more than 2,500,000 ...

GENEVA, N.Y., June 30--A second consecutive afternoon of lightning and thunder squalls, rain in such torrents that cockpits were all but filled and motors stopped and gales of wind out of the northwest that caused even the Coast Guard's 75-foot patrol boat to drag its anchor delayed until nearly dusk today the finish of the eleventh annual intercollegiate and interscholastic outboard championships on Lake Seneca.
MADRID, June 30--Reverting once again to Russia as the principal enemy of Nationalist Spain, the newspaper Arriba today expressed regret over the annexation of Bessarabia.

William R. White, New York State Superintendant of Banks, made public yesterday his annual list of securities found legal for investment by savings banks in this State. Disclosed on the list was the addition of fifty-one railroad issues aggregating $1,283,157,000 principal amount.

OTTAWA, June 30--Beginning tomorrow C.D. Howe, Minister of Munitions and Supply in Canada, and Arthur B. Purvis, purchasing agent in the United States, will take over complete control of British war purchases on this continent.

LONDON, June 30--The collapse of France and the subsequent capitulation of the Bordeaux government to the German and Italian armistice terms had serious repercussions on the stock markets here last week. The resistance that was apparent at the end of the previous week evaporated and, for a few days, the markets really looked as if they were going to pieces.

SHANGHAI, Monday, July 1--Not only has Hong Kong determined to resist further Japanese attempts at encroachment, but the Governor and the French Army commander in Indo-China, as well as the High Command of the French Fleet units in the Far East have determined upon common resistance to Japanese aggression under a unified defense, centering upon Singapore.

CHICAGO, June 29--Although the tax bill just signed by President Roosevelt provides a uniformly stiff increase in the levy on alcohol, irrespective of the purpose for which it is sold, it will not remain that way if certain influential trade groups have anything to say about it.

The report of condition of the First National Bank of the City of New York for June 29, 1940, shows total resources of $873,500,564, compared with $752,377,801 at Dec. 30, 1939, and $792,399,000 on March 26, 1940, the current total setting a new high mark.

LONDON, June 30--Air Marshal Italo Balbo, Governor of Libya, did not die in a battle with the Royal Air Force in the circumstances described by the Rome communique, the Foreign Office news department in London said tonight.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 30-- Signs of radicalism were absent today as the seventy-eighth annual convention of the National Education Association opened with an attendance which is expected to be about 11,000 when the four-day sessions get in full swing tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP)--The Browns won the first game, 7 to 6, in the eleventh inning, and the Tigers took the second, 10 to 1, in seven frames, in a double-header today. The second game was called to permit the Detroit team to catch a train.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 30-- Making his first speech in his campaign for Governor of New Jersey, Charles Edison, former Secretary of the Navy, declared here today that he would not attempt to write a prescription for New Jersey's governmental ills until he had carefully studied its problems.

LONDON, June 30--The arrival of Nazi troops at the Spanish frontier assures Germany of a direct overland route to the rich mineral resources of Spain and helps solve Chancellor Hitler's iron ore problem, it was admitted in official quarters in London tonight.

CHICAGO, June 30--Large purchases of cash lard attributed to the Red Cross, to Great Britain and to the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation brought fairly liberal buying orders for futures from packers last week, but prices held within relatively narrow limits, averaging slightly higher.

MATTITUCK, L.I., June 30-- Charles C. Heuman of 1834 Caton Avenue, Brooklyn, former president of the Maltine Company of Brooklyn, died suddenly at his Summer home this morning of a heart attack. He was 82 years old. He leaves a widow, Lulu M. Heuman, and a son, Rodney W. Heuman of Brooklyn.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30 (AP)-- The Newark Bears solidified their grip on second place today as they conquered the Baltimore Orioles in both ends of a double bill before a crowd of 6,488. They took the opener by 3--1 behind Hank Borowy's superb pitching and won the nightcap, 5--4.

Because the rolls for the Civilian Military Training Camp at Plattsburg for July were filled so rapidly and many were unable to enroll, agitation for another camp to be held in September is under way.
HONOLULU, June 30--The United States Fleet returned to Hawaiian waters today and anchored in Lahaina Roads.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)-- Nineteen of the twenty-five highest corporation salaries paid in 1938 went to movie stars and executives, the Treasury disclosed today. A $688,369 paycheck to Louis B. Mayer, head of Metro-GoldwynMayer Pictures, topped them all.

The horrors of war, graft and corruption in high places, wrongs in our economic and social systems can be changed only by individuals whose hearts and minds are permeated with the spirit of Christ and who are witnesses for Him, Bishop Charles Wesley Flint of Syracuse declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 30--Senator Burke, Nebraska Democrat, who recently introduced the Compulsory Military Training Bill, and Senator Capper, Kansas Republican, headed opposing sides in a debate on the Forum of the Air tonight over the network of the Mutual Broadcasting System on the subject: "Shall We Have Compulsory Selective Military Training and Service Now?"

Trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its direct subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, forwarded yesterday their first letter to security holders of the two bankrupt utility companies. The Rumanian Army resisted the Russian invasion yesterday in a series of sharp actions along the Pruth River, borderline between pre-World War Rumania and the province of Bessarabia, which King Carol has ceded to Russia.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 30-- The Federal Government will sell seven Guernsey cows, 7,151 chickens, 381 acres of crops in the ground and an assortment of farm machinery on Tuesday at Jersey Homesteads, four miles from here, as the latest step in the liquidation of its $4,000,000 model cooperative community, launched seven years ago.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP)--The league-leading Indians and the White Sox split a double-header today before a crowd of 20,054, the Tribe taking the first game, 7 to 5, and losing the second, 3 to 1.

PARIS, June 28 (Delayed; via Berlin)--Belgian refugees are now being repatriated by the German authorities who call for them at their center in the Rue de Berri with large trucks and trailers capable of transporting 350 persons and their baggage at once. With each caravan is a kitchen truck with a capacity for feeding all.

PARIS, June 27 (Delayed; via Berlin)--Two severe orders were issued this morning by the military authorities; one, signed by General Walther von Brauchitsch, Commander in chief of the German armies, demands that all radio sending apparatus, even that made by amateurs, be turned over to the nearest German military post.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 30-- Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Stevens, who are spending their first season here, gave a reception this afternoon at Fort Hill, their home in the Shinnecock Hills, for her mother, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt of Beaulieu, Newport, who has joined them for a visit.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., June 30--A week's celebration of the tercentenary of Southold Town began with services at the First Presbyterian Church this morning and exercises this afternoon on the estate of Allen Tobey on Goose Creek, near which the first settlers landed in early June, 1640.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP)--The Red Sox snapped out of a two-game slump today to sweep both ends of a double-header by one-run margins, defeating the Senators, 6--5 and 5--4, to gain a split in the fourgame series.

FRESNO, Calif., June 30--America's greatest track and field athletes headed homeward today, leaving behind a new and glowing chapter for the record book in the wind-up of the National A.A.U. championships.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP)--Taking both ends of a double-header for the sixth time this season, the Reds defeated the Cubs, 7 to 4 and 7 to 6, today to increase their National League lead to a game and a half over second-place Brooklyn.

FALMOUTH, Mass., July 1--Countess Geraldine Podgoursky, 40, of Boston, was killed and her husband, Count Ivan Podgoursky, was injured seriously today when their automobile struck a tree near their Summer home in West Falmouth.

Home from the Republican convention, where her husband was named its Presidential candidate, Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie found that the usual peace at the apartment at 1010 Fifth Avenue had vanished yesterday and in its place was a rush of mail, visitors and gifts.

Charles H. Chatfield has been made executive assistant to the vice president of the United Aircraft Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Raycroft Walsh, vice president. Frank W. Caldwell was named director of research.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The first step in a training program that is expected ultimately to cover 1,500,000 youths was taken today when President Roosevelt approved a project that will permit the immediate training of 150,000 workers for the defense program.

The Holland-America liner Volendam arrived here yesterday under British control with 223 passengers, including seventy-nine children-being removed from England for the duration of the war. Many of the passengers were en route to their homes in Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

LONDON, July 1--Nobody at the French Liberation headquarters believes the tale of an automobile accident befalling former Premier Paul Reynaud. Refugees from Bordeaux bluntly say that he was "taken for a ride" by the Gestapo to prevent his flight to Morocco to form an anti-Nazi government.

The "two-ocean" Navy already approved by the House is now before the Senate. Involving a proposed increase of 70 per cent in the present Navy, and 200 more ships and their accessories to be built in the next six years at an estimated cost of $4,000,000,000, this proposal must raise many questions in the mind of the ordinary citizen.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 1--Hungary was on a war footing tonight with troops massed along the border of Transylvania, which Hungary lost to Rumania in 1918.

Joseph Paul-Boncour, former Premier of France, is expected to arrive at La Guardia Field today aboard the Atlantic Clipper of Pan American Airways, it was reported yesterday at the airport.
The Engineers Public Service Company and Subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on May 31 a net income of $5,604,615 after all expenses and charges.

Retailers and amusement houses with some exceptions were agreed yesterday that the new defense taxes imposed by the Federal Government had produced no marked effect on sales of liquors, cigarettes, radios and tickets of admission.

CHICAGO, July 1--Record-breaking attendance figures, unusually heavy early buying and a note of warning against inventory speculation featured the opening of the midsummer furniture and home furnishings markets here today.

Nat J. Greene has resold for all cash to an investing client of Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc., the twelve-story loft building at 48-52 East Twenty-first Street, running through to 49 East Twentieth Street, which he acquired last month from Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, July 1--The fiftyone-minute session of the Senate today was marked by an attack by Senator Pepper of Florida upon the nomination of Wendell L. Willkie by the Republican party.
WASHINGTON, July 1--Week end contributions brought the American Red Cross War Relief Fund almost to within $3,000,000 of the $20,000,000 goal which has been fixed.

Apparently refreshed by his weekend cruise on the yacht Jamaroy, owned by Roy W. Howard, newspaper publisher, Wendell L. Willkie, Republican nominee for President, expressed hope yesterday that President Roosevelt would run for a third term.

WASHINGTON, July 1--A "steeply graduated excess profits tax" on all individuals and corporations to help finance the outlay of $4,300,700,000 voted by Congress for national defense in the fiscal year 1941 was recommended by President Roosevelt today in a brief and unexpected message to Congress.

Wilkerson on his plea of guilty to income-tax evasion.

Ten of the eleven attractions now playing the Broadway scene will celebrate Independence Day by giving matinee performances. Those for which the normal day is Wednesday simply will move to Thursday.

Although there were few if any perfect days in June, Dr. James H. Kimball, meteorologist for the local Weather Bureau, yesterday presented an array of statistics by which he upset a popular belief that last month was too cold. BUFFALO, N.Y., July 2 (AP)-- Albert J. Wright, retired blind dean of Buffalo brokers, died today at his Summer home in Cazenovia, after a brief illness at the age of 81.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, announced yesterday the dismissal of Thomas Corwin, an artist employed on the art project, for preparing Communist propaganda while working for the WPA. Robert Godsoe, a supervisor on the project, also was dismissed for incompetence in submitting Corwin's poster for approval by the WPA.

CHICAGO, July 2--Banks in Chicago are lending more and have larger cash resources and deposits than three months ago or a year ago, according to figures made public today in response to Federal and State calls for statements of condition as of June 29.

Munro, director of public and international affairis at Princeton University.

STOCKHOLM, July 2--Voicing the opinion of authoritative Swedish quarters the Svenska Dagbladet today issued an appeal for a compromise peace between Germany and Britain and urged that a mediator step forward to initiate negotiations to that end.

MILWAUKEE, July 2--A strong trend toward adoption of a resolution favoring compulsory military service appeared to be developing today among the delegates to the convention of the National Education Association, the organization of teachers which has a membership of 203,000.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, July 1 (Delayed)--Three weeks ago today THE NEW YORK TIMES Bureau left for the south in the wake of the French Government, which since then has scarcely ever ceased moving. It had no sooner arrived here than it considered moving on to Vichy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2-- The Secor Farms Riding Club held its second annual horse show on the club grounds today, with a huge number of classes and a very large entry. Delightful weather and clever management made it possible to complete the program practically according to schedule.

Despite some gains in reducing accidents caused by fireworks, the sale of which is now outlawed to minors in many localities, July has a bad record of accidental death in the nation. The National Safety, Council reports that for the month last year the accident toll in all categories was 8,800 dead and 800,000 injured.

Economic conditions in Nicaragua are good in spite of the war, Colo nel Irving T. Lindberg, Collector of Customs and High Commissioner of Nicaragua, said yesterday upon his arrival here form Central America.

This makes a total of twenty-five either dismissed, fined or retired as a result of the investigation.

The Giants and the Bees were locked in a very tight ball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but it wasn't a very solid lock. The Bostonians jimmied it open with a pair of homers off Hal Schumacher in the sixth and won, 5 to 3. This was a very untimely setback for the New Yorkers, since it left them two full lengths behind the Dodgers on the eve of an all-important interborough series.

WASHINGTON, July 2--Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, having shaken off the effects of the back injury which sent him into drydock on April 19, informed Manager Joe McCarthy that he was ready, willing and able to return to work today, so the Yankee pilot granted Lefty's request for a starting assignment against the Senators at Griffith Stadium.

A reorganization plan for the Norfolk Southern Railroad has been approved by the Federal court in Norfolk, Va., Carrol M. Shanks of the Prudential Insurance Company, reorganization manager, announced yesterday. At the same time he asked for the deposit of securities in support of the plan.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 2 --The United States cruisers Wichita and Quincy, under command of Rear Admiral A.C. Pickens, will leave here tomorrow bound northward for an unannounced destination. It is reported their first call will be at Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.

More teachers testified yesterday at the third day of the Board of Education's trial of Dr. Charles J. Pickett, principal of Samuel Gompers Vocational High School, that they were assigned to classrooms that already contained regular teachers, and that they taught in subjects for which they were not licensed.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,639,550 barrels, a drop of 206,900 from the 3,846,450 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 19,250 barrels ...

Mayor La Guardia appointed yesterday Ira A. Hirschmann, vice president of Bloomingdale's department store, as a member of the Board of Higher Education to succeed Albert Weiss of 910 West End Avenue, whose term expired.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP)--The scrappy Browns, relishing their role as Giant Killers, knocked Cleveland out of first place today. Relief Pitcher Nate Andrews, former Brownie, served a ninth-inning home-run ball to his rival, Vernon Kennedy, which gave St. Louis a 5-to-3 victory--its second straight over the skidding Tribe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2-- Ernst Lubitsch, who is producing for United Artists in partnership with Sol Lesser, has purchased "Kiss Me Again," based on the French play "Divorcons" by Victorien Sardou and Emile de Majac, from Paramount for $27,000, it was learned today.

PITTSBURGH, July 2--Edmund I. Kaufmann, Washington philanthropist and business leader, was elected president of the Zionist Organization of America at the closing session of the convention. Mr. Kaufmann succeeds Dr. Solomon Goldman, retiring president.

WASHINGTON, July 2--Four of the twelve largest cities for which preliminary figures are available declined in population in the decade since 1930 and three others remained almost stationary, the Census Bureau said today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 2-- Two-Ton Tony Galento, barrelshaped Orange, N.J., heavyweight, came to the end of the pugilistic trail tonight at Roosevelt Stadium.
TRENTON, July 2--The New Jersey Legislature recessed technically early today until Nov. 12, but the Senate, and the Assembly as well, may reconvene on Thursday of next week.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 2 (UP)--Hungary tonight was believed to be urging Germany and Italy to allow her to wrest Transylvania from Rumania either by diplomatic or military action.

WASHINGTON, July 2--Legislation authorizing construction in New York Harbor of a drydock capable of accommodating the 45,000ton battleships being built by the Navy was approved today by the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 2--Continuing to attack Italian gasoline supplies, planes of the British Royal Air Force were reported to have blown up an oil refinery and tanks at Augusta on the east coast of Sicily in a raid carried out yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 2-- The situation here is somewhat calmer today. There have been no further reports of incidents on the Hungarian frontier nor any indications that Russian ambitions extend beyond the Pruth River.

The Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday was largely concentrated in the uptown area, with many residential parcels in Harlem and the West Side going into new hands.

WASHINGTON, July 2--President Roosevelt put a virtual embargo today on the sale to foreign countries of any munitions, materials or machinery needed in the national defense program. By proclamation he subjected all such shipments to rigid control under military direction.
ALBANY, July 2--Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti was designated today by Governor Lehman as coordinator of State activities in the national defense program.

In only two notable instances is there any major deviation between public sentiment and the program of action advocated in the Republican platform adopted at Philadelphia, surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion have revealed, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP)-- The Curtis Publishing Company's stockholders today voted to accept a recapitalization plan designed to reduce its annual dividend required on the $7 preferred stock from $5,056,940 to $3,356,406.

WASHINGTON, July 2--President Roosevelt refrained from any assurance that he would not be a candidate for a third term in offering Colonel Frank Knox the secretaryship of the navy, the Chicago publisher, who was the Republicans' 1936 Vice Presidential candidate, today assured the Naval Affairs Committee, to which his nomination had been referred.

Quiet trading on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday, but reports that July 1 condition of the growing crop was below normal drew in a sufficient volume of buying to offset adverse factors, with the result that the close was at a gain of 3 points to a loss of 8.
After crashing into an abutment on the West Side Highway at Seventy-second Street yesterday morning, two men trapped in a blazing automobile were rescued by painters working near that point.

ALBANY, July 2--Governor Lehman made public today statistics painting a rosy picture of the State's financial condition as of June 30, which indicated that the revenues and the expenditures for the fiscal year have almost exactly equalled the estimates made last January. Surpluses were shown in several tax classifications.

Various agencies here continued yesterday with their efforts to raise funds to bring European children to this continent, to provide relief for refugees and other war sufferers and to buy ambulances to send to England.
RYE, N.Y., July 2--Ed Overton of Pelham and Jack Selby of Oakland, Calif., shared the honors today in the first day's play of the Westchester junior golf championship over the Apawamis Club course.

WASHINGTON, July 2--President Roosevelt refused today to disclose his 1940 political plans despite insistent press conference questions. Although the questions were many and varied, the President was consistently uncommunicative.

In just about the tightest nose finish he ever will survive, Dudie, a home-bred of W.H. Gallagher, captured the best race at Empire City yesterday. John Hay Whitney's Counterglow, gaining with every stride through the last furlong, was the one to make things so close that a camera verdict was necessary. Three lengths away Great Albert was third.

LONDON, July 2--The British Government was urged from all sides in the House of Commons today to speed its plans to send thousands of children to the United States for the duration of the war and if possible get the United States Navy to convoy the floating nurseries across the Atlantic.

OTTAWA, July 2--Statements by the Air Minister and the Minister of Munitions and Supply in the House of Commons today show the increasing emphasis that this government is placing on the speedy strengthening of Canada's air arm. Both statements reported progress beyond expectation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2--Displaying his best form since his nohit game against the Reds, Tex Carleton today limited the Phillies to three hits as the Dodgers beat them, 4--1, for a sweep of the twogame series.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., July 2-- The hammer of the auctioneer pounded again today in Jersey Homesteads, as the Farm Security Administration bought in the colony's growing crops and farm supplies and equipment.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 2-- Theodore Brentano, retired diplomat and former Chief Justice in Cook County of the Illinois State Superior Court, died here today of heart disease at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Carola B. Anderson, 105 Ocean Avenue. He was 86 years old.

"The Ghost Breakers" is the new attraction today at the Paramount. Replete with a haunted castle and, of course, ghosts, placed in a Cuban setting, the comedy co-stars Paulette Goddard and Bob Hope. The supporting cast includes Richard Carlson, Paul Lukas and Willie Best.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2-- Mr. and Mrs. Valentine E. Macy Jr. gave a dinner tonight at their home on the ocean for 'Mrs. Macy's son, George W. Helm Jr., to celebrate the latter's eighteenth birthday. Later Mr. and Mrs. Macy took their party to the Canoe Place Inn for supper and dancing.

A crowd of 4,500 children from twenty-seven orphan homes of all denominations in the city gave vocal expression to their glee yesterday as they were entertained at the fourth annual orphan's day outing sponsored by the Police Anchor Club.

ROME, July 2--Premier Mussolini, in a letter to the Prince of Piedmont this morning, proclaimed to all Italians and foreigners that the Italian Ariny had won great glory in the battle fought on the French frontier in the last four days of hostilities against France.

HAVANA, July 2--Cuba will support any measures necessary to defend the peace of this hemisphere, but will postpone a decision regarding economic cooperation until "it is determined what collaboration is desired from Cuba," the Cabinet meeting decided this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would continue export subsidy of programs on cotton products, wheat and wheat flour in the fiscal year that began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2--The Senate Military Affairs Committee today voted to recommend confirmation of Henry L. Stimson as Secretary of War. The vote of 14 to 3 came after two hours of questioning in which he defended his views on national defense and aid to the Allies and asserted that his appointment to the Cabinet had "no relation to politics whatever."

The United States liner Manhattan, the third American ship assigned recently to go to Europe to bring back Americans, sailed for Lisbon at 1:15 P.M. yesterday. She is expected to reach Portugal next Monday and will sail for home as soon as all her passengers have embarked.

PARIS, June 30 (Delayed; via Berlin)--The first signs of impatience were noted in the public markets today when women were unable to obtain food. They blamed the government for not stopping the millions of refugees who are crowding the roads, hindering transportation.

The City Council, in its last regular session of the Summer, passed yesterday a local law designed to protect persons bringing negligence and other actions against the city from the mistakes of their own lawyers and a law to grant limited tax exemption to housing projects of housing companies under the public housing law.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Wednesday, July 3 (AP)--General H. G. Winkelman, the Netherlands Commander in Chief, has been transported to Germany as a war prisoner, it was officially announced today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 2 (London Times dispatch)--General Maxime Weygand is reported to have arrived at Damascus to deal with the situation in Syria. According to information from foreign sources, Germany and Italy are sending representatives to Beirut.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 2-- Tony Galento weighed 244 pounds, twenty-three more than Max Baer, for their battle tonight in Roosevelt Stadium.

For a record of consistency, Dini from the stable of W.C. Winfrey has few equals in racing. This 4year-old daughter of John P. Grier thrilled a crowd of 10,213 that bet $569,014 at Empire City yesterday as she galloped home an easy winner of the Celandria Handicap for fillies and mares.

William Saroyan's "Sweeney in the Trees" will be tried out this Summer, after all. The place will be the Cape Theatre, Cape May, N.J., and the week. of Aug. 6, the probable time. Julie Haydon will have a role, but the director has not been chosen, so far.

DENNIS, Mass., Thursday, July 4--Gertrude Lawrence, English actress, and Richard S. Aldrich, producer and manager of the Cape Playhouse here, were married at one minute after midnight at the home of the late Raymond Moore, founder of the theatre.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Representatives of the securities industry had their final conference with the Securities and Exchange Commission today before returning home to report to their associations the proposal of the SEC to seek immediate legislation to relax the twenty-day waiting period required for issues of new securities.

New York City along with the rest of the nation will celebrate today the 164th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence with patriotic ceremonies that will reflect the spirit of preparedness in the country.
The first practical step in the American Women's Defense Corps program of training women for home defense was taken yesterday with the delivery of an ambulance for use by the group.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3-- Metro announced today that Laraine Day will play the feminine lead in "Adventure for Three," by Marcella Burke and R.B. Wills, which the studio has had on its schedule for two years.

ROME, July 3--The British Government yesterday notified Pope Pius that it recognized the sacred character of Rome and that so far as it is possible will not bomb or shell or damage the city, Vatican quarters said today. This assurance was given to the Pope by D'Arcy Osborne, British Minister to the Vatican.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 3--Professor and Mrs. Philip Marshall Brown of Washington were hosts tonight at a barn dance at Brownfields, South Williamstown. A group of fiddlers played tunes of horse-and-buggy days for lancers, Virginia reel and money musk.
Borrowing on collateral by members of the New York Stock Exchange on June 29 dropped to the lowest ratio to market value of listed stocks in the history of the institution.

Three women were among the ninety college students who began taking instruction yesterday as air pilots at New York University, which is cooperating with the Civil Aeronautics Authority's new Summer program.

I have been asked to express my views on Senator Burke's and Representative Wadsworth's bill before this committee, because I have occupied for some years a position in close contact with the education of young men of college and university age.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the first quarter of this year, made public yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, showed a net income of $406,500 after operating expenses and other deductions but before any provision for possible losses resulting from the European war.

It must have been an absent-minded artist who decorated Mayor La Guardia's subway poster-appeal for a safe and sane Fourth with a burst of red explosion in an upper corner. But the official invitation to peace and quiet is a necessary reminder.

Fur sales by members of the American Fur Merchants Association showed an increase of 33.1 per cent for the period from December through May in comparison with the same months a year ago, acoording to the report issued yesterday by that organization.

More than nine-tenths of the cases handled by the State Labor Relations Board in the first three years of its existence were adjusted without formal proceedings, the board declared in its annual report made public yesterday.

BOSTON, July 3--After suffering its second disappointment in two days, the Suffolk Downs management announced today the line-up of the eleven 3-year-olds that will go to the post in the $15,000-added Yankee Handicap of a mile and three-sixteenths tomorrow.

RYE, N.Y., July 3--Wind flaws that could not have been more complete had they come from a loosejointed electric fan, made weird sailing in the American Yacht Club's championship series regatta today, the first session of the five days of over-the-holiday racing on the Sound.

Officials of Nassau County, L.I., will be in the market on July 15 with an issue of $2,350,000 of relief, public works and refunding bonds, for which bidders are to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, to be dated Aug. 1, will mature serially on Aug. 1, 1941 to 1955.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 3-- Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson gave a dinner and bridge to night at The Crossways for Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe of Planting Fields, Oyster Bay, who have joined them for the holiday and week-end.
The extent of Nazi penetration in South America is a matter of dispute. The extent of Nazi insolence in the same area is not.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3--The unexpected elimination of Larry Dee, Stanford University ace, who paired with James Wade, also of Stanford, to capture the national intercollegiate doubles crown earlier this week in Philadelphia, featured the third day's play in the varsity singles of the eighteenth annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Dr. Elias Lieberman, newly elected Associate Superintendent of Schools, has been placed in charge of the junior high school division, a function heretofore combined with that of directing the senior high schools, it was learned yesterday from Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
LONDON, Thursday, July 4--Nazi air attacks against Great Britain took on new boldness yesterday with sporadic daylight raids on Scotland, England and Wales lasting from morning until evening.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Two States, Montana and Nevada, have reached the total goals of all their chapters in the American Red Cross $20,000,000 war relief fund drive, the relief agency announced today, coincident with its announcement that contributions to date now total $17,547,441. Virginia was runner-up, with its chapters having obtained 87.39 per cent of their goals.
The British Navy is forcibly taking control over French naval ships in British ports, it was announced in London this morning.

RYE, N.Y., July 3--In an allPrinceton final today Jack Selby of Oakland, Calif., captured the Westchester junior golf crown by defeating his college team-mate, W. Mitchell Jennings, by 4 and 2, over the Apawamis Club course.

Max Baer was up bright and early yesterday for a visit to the offices of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club. Accompanying the former heavyweight champion of the world was his 2-year-old son, whom Max proudly displayed to every one he saw.
The organization of child refugee placement in the United States was speeded further yesterday to keep up with a flood of offers of homes or funds for children between the ages of 5 and 16 years.

In connection with the usual preFourth-of-July expansion of currency in circulation, Wall Street banks reported yesterday an unprecedented holiday increase in the demand for coin. This demand favored nickels, dimes and quarters, with the request for pennies showing a smaller increase.

A total of $206,123 for the relief of Dutch refugees had been collected yesterday throughout the country by the Queen Wilhelmina Fund, Inc., while other agencies soliciting funds to aid European children, to help British civilians and military forces and to buy ambulances for the British Army also reported progress.
For twenty years we have talked about the need of a drydock in the New York district--a drydock large enough to accommodate battleships and liners.

The bang of firecrackers, salutes, torpedoes and other old-fashioned noise makers will be strictly on a bootleg basis in New York City this year, with the sources of bootleg supply more remote than last year.
An apartment of twelve rooms and four baths in 1 Sutton Place has been leased by Mrs.William J. Sturgis through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. B.

All security and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Independence Day. Many livestock markets which ordinarily remain open on holidays also will be closed. All banking institutions throughout the country will observe the holiday.

BASEBALL has its honored traditions. One of them is celebrated annually with the Fourth of July. This is the day when the managers of last-place clubs in various leagues gather their hopeful hirelings about them and tell them the tale of the Boston Braves of 1914.

Appointment of a committee on national defense at Columbia University to supervise and consolidate the university's efforts in cooperation with the government was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.
CHICAGO, July 3--The first three days of the midsummer furnishings market here ended with sales running ahead of last year and attendance increasing even more sharply.

BERLIN, July 3 (UP)--General H.K.A. von Winterfeldt, one of the four German plenipotentiaries at the armistice negotiations in Compiegne Forest in 1918, died today of a heart attack induced by the heat.
Brisk advances in the pound sterling and the Canadian dollar featured trading in the free market for foreign exchange yesterday.

ABOUT fifteen years ago Harold E. Briggs, who was born in Minnesota and is now Pro fessor of History at the University of Miami (Coral Gables, Fla.), began collecting data on pioneer days in the Upper Missouri Valley. Much of the material he came across, or perhaps most of it, is brought together in "Frontiers of the Northwest," 600 pages long and packed with an array of about 600,000 facts.

Two young brides from Brittany, grand nieces of the late Major Gen. Henry P. Davison, the J.P. Morgan partner who headed the Red Cross during the World War, arrived as refugees yesterday on the Yankee Clipper. Romance has just begun for one of the sisters and a war tragedy has ended the romance of the other.

A stubborn five-hour fire of undetermined origin which swept the after holds of the Clyde Mallory liner Algonquin yesterday, two hours before the vessel was to have sailed with 160 vacation-bound passengers, resulted in the injury of twenty-four firemen, tied up holiday traffic in lower New York and caused fears for the safety of the Holland Tunnel.
LONDON, July 3--From India has come a report suggesting formation of a coalition government in India for the purpose of throwing the weight of that subcontinent behind Britain's war effort.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Favorable and unfavorable factors in the week's world trade developments, as reported to the Commerce Department in cables and radiograms from its attaches abroad, were listed by the department today as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 3--The State Department was deluged with inquiries today by telephone and telegraph from business concerns because of uncertainty over the extent to which basic materials and products are subject to license for export under the act proclaimed by...

BOSTON, July 3 (AP)--A special Massachusetts commission investigating pardons and paroles reported today that it had reached the "inescapable conclusion that money was the moving cause" in obtaining some pardons between 1931 and 1938, and recommended that impeachment proceedings be started against those responsible.

The majority of the 800 men who are to attend the first Plattsburg camp of 1940 will entrain at the Grand Central Terminal tonight at 10 o'clock, as such men did twentyfive years ago when preparedness first produced "The Plattsburg Idea."

The full force of the national defense program on the steel industry is not expected to be experienced in less than ninety days, according to Iron Age, which says that the Navy program is being accelerated, "but military production of arms and airplanes is still delayed in Washington, notwithstanding the anxiety of manufacturers to learn what they are expected to do.

John Bull did not get his nickname for nothing. His determination in this war was never more clearly revealed than early this morning when the Government announced that all units of the French fleet that lay in British ports had been placed under British control.

After twenty years as a cooperative, the seven-story apartment building at 98 Morningside Avenue, southwest corner of 123d Street, will pass to single ownership and be occupied by colored families. It was sold yesterday by the forty tenants in the cooperative group to an investing client of Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

Professor George Cann Minard, a member of the faculty of the School of Education of New York University since 1925, died last night of a heart attack at his residence, the Hotel Earle, 103 Waverly Place, a few moments after the arrival of his wife, Mrs. Carlotta McDonnough ...

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 3 (UP)--In an effort to obtain her territorial aspirations without resorting to war, Hungary was believed ready tonight to negotiate with Rumania concerning the future of Transylvania.

LONDON, July 3--In this confused world in which we are living, it is not impossible that the onetime Allies may become enemies and that powers that formerly were verging on war may be driven toward friendlier relations, at least where economics are concerned.
WASHINGTON, July 3--Secretary Ickes approved today opinions expressed by Wendell L. Willkie on matters of foreign policy, but deplored his views on other major issues.

Confusion reminiscent of that existing here when the Neutrality Act first went into force developed in the foreign trade community yesterday following President Roosevelt's proclamation imposing an embargo on the export of key materials.

CHICAGO, July 3--If England holds off the Nazi invasion, the pinch of dwindling food supplies may be felt by September in Germany, Italy and the countries they dominate, in the opinion of Colonel Edward N. Wentworth, director of the livestock bureau of Armour Co.

Ten residential holdings of the Central Savings Bank were sold in a group in one of the Bronx realty deals announced yesterday. In another transaction four apartment houses in the same borough were taken by one purchaser.

LONDON, July 3--The British reply to the Japanese request for the closing of the Burma road into China is now being prepared and may be sent in the next few days. The nature of the reply is not known yet, but the British are expected to refuse very politely.

NEWARK, N.J., July 3--Unless the State provides funds for the sponsors' share, about 14,000 persons will be discharged from white collar and professional projects of tha WPA in New Jersey, it was announced today by Robert W. Allan, State WPA Administrator.

MILWAUKEE, July 3--"All the fruits of more than a century and a half of effort to develop the democratic way of life are at this moment in deadly jeopardy," John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, told the annual meeting of the National Education Association tonight.

SOMEWHERE ON THE BRITISH COAST, July 3--One of the crack divisions of the British Army holds this area today. It had a magnificent record in Flanders and later in the bloody "Battle of the Beaches" around Dunkerque.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)--The United States and Canadian Governments are smoothing out immigration and currency difficulties, in an effort to maintain tourist relations between the two countries as nearly normal as possible under wartime conditions.
Nervousness over persistent rainfall in western sections of the Cotton Belt created yesterday a definite "weather market" on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices advanced 2 to 15 points.

OTTAWA, July 3--Lady May Abel Smith formerly Lady May Cambridge, daughter of Princess Alice and the Governor General of Canada, arrived with her three children at Rideau Hall this afternoon to join Princess Juliana of the Netherlands and her two baby daughters for a prolonged stay as guests of her parents.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP)--The Indians called upon young Bob Feller today to stop the Browns from kicking them around. Feller responded with a seven-hit, 5-to-2 triumph which returned the Indians to the American League lead they lost to Detroit yesterday.

Sixth Avenue, so long a Cinderella, is on her way to become a princess among streets. Yesterday work began on what is to be a transformation, a new beauty and the reappearance, splendidly housed, of old favorites long missed.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Republican party was accused tonight by Senator Byrnes of South Carolina of having planted "poison" with the public over our national defense preparations for partisan advantage.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 3-- According to reports filtering through from Norway, German military quarters in that country are looking forward to July 9 or 10 as the day on which the invasion of Britain is to begin.

LONDON, July 3 (AP)--A dispatch by Havas, French news agency, from Vichy, France, said today that the French Government would call a national assembly "to give France a new Constitution under the high authority of Marshal Petain."

AUSTIN, Texas, July 3--Statements to the effect that "Hitler is a monster who must be stamped out," and that the United States must carry out to the utmost its defense program were made in several papers and in discussion on a variety of economic and related subjects at the sessions of the Institute of Latin-American Studies, which closed a two-day program at the University of Texas today.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP)--The Red Sox spotted the Athletics the first eight runs today and then set off enough fireworks to gain a 12-11 victory that was decided by Captain Jimmy Foxx's homer, his nineteenth of the season.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The original strategy of the New Deal engineers of the third term draft for the President was a three-point plan.

BERLIN, July 3 (UP)--The German Foreign Office claimed tonight to have proof in a series of "war guilt" documents that Britain and France had drawn up detailed plans four months ago for an air attack on Russia by way of Turkey.
Lady Mendl, the former Elsie de Wolfe, stepped spryly out of the Yankee Clipper at La Guardia Airport yesterday with her husband, Sir Charles Mendl, the British diplomat.

TOKYO, July 3--A potential political crisis that has been brewing behind the scenes since the foreign policy speech of Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita was dispelled tonight when the Japanese radio broadcast an official statement that the Foreign Office and the War Office had reached an agreement. The statement, issued jointly by the two offices, reads:
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)--The Treasury Department started its new fiscal year with a deficit of $120,674,733 on the first day.

The first bedraggled contingent of American and Canadian Finnish volunteers to return home arrived here yesterday morning on the 3,641-ton Finnish-American freighter Mathilda Thorden. All but a handful of them had been frustrated in their mission of fighting for their homeland, for the war ended before they were put in service.

President Roosevelt prepared yesterday for submission to Congress Monday a supplemental defense program calling for $5,000,000,000 more, $4,000,000,000 to go to the Army and $1,000,000,000 to the Navy.

MOSCOW, July 3--The newspaper Trud reported today that the Red Army commander at Cernauti had informed peasants that within the next few days land would be taken from big estate owners and distributed to landless farmers.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 3--British Blenheim bombers escorted by Gladiator fighters yesterday morning exploded a bomb dump at the Macaaca airdrome in Italian East Africa and fired two gasoline dumps, according to an R.A.F. communiqu today.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP)--Charles S. Howard's Advocator, erstwhile plater that stepped into the racing shoes of Seabiscuit and Kayak II, probably will go to the post the favorite in the Stars and Stripes Handicap, mile and a furlong stake at Arlington Park tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Securities and Exchange Commission today permitted the Ogden Corporation, successor in reorganization to the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, to borrow $4,400,000 at 2 per cent from the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York...

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 3-- Rand Stevens, 41 years old, arrested here Monday with a young woman companion on charges of being disorderly persons after police found alleged Communist party records in their automobile, is the nephew of Raymond B. Stevens, chairman of the Federal Tariff Commission and former adviser to the King of Siam, it became known today.

In a unanimous decision published yesterday the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court ruled that a tenant on a month-to-month or monthly basis was not required to give his landlord any notice of his intention to vacate.
WASHINGTON, July 3--Hachiro Arita, Japan's Foreign Minister, issued a statement on April 17 expressing hope that the status quo of the Netherlands Indies would be preserved.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The most prolonged dry spell the District of Columbia has had in years came to an end today, washing out the finale of the series between the Yankees and Senators. The postponed game will be played as part of a doubleheader on the next visit of the world champions.

The sixteen-family apartment house at 2066-68 East Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Fenton Housing Company to a client of Eugene J. Keely, Inc., brokers, for cash above a first mortgage of $19,500.

Of those members of the National Association of Independent Tire Dealers, who cooperated with tire manufacturers sponsoring special sales from May 15 to 30, 52.2 per cent reported that the benefits of the sale advertising extended to lines of tires other than those advertised, chiefly higher-price tires.
LONDON, Thursday, July 4--All units of the French Fleet in British ports were put under British control yesterday, the Ministry of Information revealed in a sudden announcement early this morning.

Looking forward confidently to the four-day week-end beginning with the many-phased Fourth of July program today, the World's Fair kept right on breaking attendance records yesterday, although the seemingly inevitable rain cut down the turnout last night.

Mayor La Guardia in a Fourth of July speech made public last night before its delivery over WNYC from the City Building at the World's Fair at 7 A.M. today urges a strong national defense program as the only practical means of preserving American civil liberties.

WASHINGTON, July 3--President Roosevelt's nomination of Colonel Frank Knox as Secretary of the Navy was recommended to the Sen-. ate for confirmation by its Naval Affairs Committee today by a vote of 9 to 5, with two members absent and not voting.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 3--Stuart Warner Cramer, nationally known textile industry leader, died at his home here of a heart ailment last night. His age was 72.

A crowd of more than 2,000 persons attended an "independence rally" of the Christian Front last night in Prospect Hall, 261 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn. Eight of the defendants in the recent sedition trial in Brooklyn Federal Court were guests of honor and were cheered by the audience.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Mass production of Rolls-Royce airplane engines in the United States seemed assured today when William S. Knudsen, member of the National Defense Advisory Commission in charge of production, announced that the Packard Motor Car Company had tentatively agreed to undertake the task.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 3-- At noon today the Russian occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina was completed and the last Rumanian soldiers had withdrawn from the ceded territories.

LONDON, July 3--Zigzagging westward across the Atlantic with 1,640 German and Italian prisoners sleeping down below and armed British soldiers patrolling her decks, the British prison ship Arandora Star, 15,501 tons, was torpedoed by a German submarine shortly after dawn yesterday morning.
BERLIN, July 3--The French liner Champlain, according to a German news agency report from Geneva, struck a mine at la Pallice, France, seventy-five miles north of Bordeaux, a few days ago and sank.

When the fiscal year ended at midnight Sunday, the Federal Government recorded its tenth consecutive deficit. The deficit this time amounted to $3,612,000,000, larger than that of any other New Deal year except 1936, when the veterans' bonus was paid.

WASHINGTON, July 3--After two hours of secret discussion with three high officers of the Navy, the Senate Naval Affairs Committee voted unanimously today to recommend Senate passage of the House bill to authorize an increase over the next six years of 70 per cent in the Navy combatant tonnage at an estimated cost of S4,000,000,000.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 3--The French islands, Martinique and Guadeloupe are in a difficult situation as a result of the French collapse, according to word received here yesterday.

After Dr. Louis I. Dublin had revealed yesterday that the proposed permanent museum of health would be located in a large building at the World's Fair rather than in the city, as had been planned originally, Mayor La Guardia confirmed that the probable site would be the $300,000 building now housing the $30,000,000 masterpieces of art exhibition.

Party labels will mean less to the voters at the November election than support or opposition to the New Deal, Wendell L. Willkie, Republican nominee for President, declared yesterday at his daily press interview at his office at 20 Pine Street.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 3--In one of the largest Citizens Military Training Camps in the United States, more than 2,300 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware will begin here on Friday a thirty-day training period, it was announced today.

COLLEGE CAMP, Wis., July 3-- The American Youth Congress began its sixth annual convention here this evening with every sign of enthusiasm on the part of about 600 delegates and observers from all parts of the country, but with reported discord within the organization and attacks on it from without its ranks.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3--Many dinner parties were given tonight before the Radium Ball, which took place on the enclosed front lawn of the Casino. The ball was for the benefit of the Newport County Radium Fund for the Treatment of Cancer Cases.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3--President Roberto M. Ortiz of Argentina relinquished tonight the duties of his office temporarily because of ill health. He has long been a sufferer from diabetes. He took office Feb. 20, 1938.

Mayor La Guardia approved a new set of regulations covering the sale of theatre tickets yesterday and expressed the hope that they would drive ticket speculators who charge exorbitant prices out of business.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Erwin R. Hilts to Earle H. Rodney of Fuller, Rodney Co.; from George D. Wick Jr. to Raymond de Clairville of Gwynne Brothers, from Valentine A. Ely to...
Investors were active in the Bronx realty trading yesterday when deals involving a number of large apartment properties were announced by brokers.

Time, which World's Fair 1939 so courageously tried to hurry, is, we're sorry to report, in full retreat on the Meadow. There are still some places on the grounds where wistful escapists peer dubiously into the thin mirage of the World of Tomorrow, but the trend, beyond question, is toward deeper and deeper yesterdays.

ROME, July 3--Preparations for the attack against Great Britain have been virtually completed by the Axis Powers. The attack is a question of "days, if not hours," according to the Telegrafo, of Leghorn, the Ciano family newspaper.

Shattering the peacetime recruiting record for the third time in less than a week, the Second Corps Area enlisted 137 new soldiers on Tuesday, bettering by ten the previous daily high for New York, New Jersey and Delaware, it was announced yesterday by the army recruiting bureau at 39 Whitehall Street.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)--The President has signed legislation making possible correction of an error made seventy years ago when a small burial plot containing the remains of veterans of the War of 1812 was left out of the Cypress Hills National Cemetery in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP)-- President Roosevelt's failure to take even his closest friends and party leaders into his confidence on third-term plans was reported tonight to have severed virtually the last tie between the Chief Executive and Postmaster General James A. Farley, manager of the 1932-1936 Democratic campaigns and Chairman of the National Democratic Committee.

LONDON, July 3--After a strong opening in some sections the stock markets turned lower this afternoon. Profit-taking left its mark, mainly in the home industrial list. For example, motors, chemicals and rayons lost their previous gains and tobaccos were dull, but breweries and iron and steels held their earlier improvements.

Wendell L. Willkie, Republican Presidential nominee, visited the Radio City Music Hall last evening to witness the premiere of an "Information Please" motion picture presenting Mr. Willkie as one of the four members of the board of experts.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP)--Joe Burk of the Penn A.C., Philadelphia, continued his 1940 sculling drive by easily winning the senior singles, one of the features in the annual People's Day regatta on the Schuylkill River today before 10,000 spectators.
STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP)--The favorite, Masked General, easily won the $10,000 added Sussex Handicap, feature of the closing day program at Delaware Park today before a record crowd of 25,000.
DURHAM, N.Y., July 4--State troopers in Greene County today started looking for the persons who removed within the last few days an old milestone from the farm owned by Brooks Atkinson in this town.
ROME, July 4--Vatican authorities are applying with great severity measures to insure the strict neutrality of residents of Vatican City, it was stated today.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4-- There was a round of entertaining today for the holiday guests at estates in the colony.
We grow confused, sometimes, trying to keep up with variations of the fan dance as they accrue on Peacock Prairie. Yesterday, for example, we heard of another.

Leslie Smith, retired educator and former president of the Board of Education of the Far Rockaway School District, died yesterday in his home at 2325 Healy Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens, after an illness of several months.

LONDON, July 4--Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today that the rule of self-preservation had forced the British Navy to turn its guns on former brothers-in-arms to prevent the French Fleet from falling into enemy hands through the "malevolent" peace that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had made with Chancellor Hitler.

CHICAGO, July 4--Miss Sonja Henie, figure-skating champion and moving-picture star, was married this afternoon to Daniel Reid Topping, sportsman and owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers football team. The couple arrived here last night.

NEWARK, July 4 (AP)--The Jersey City Giants, after losing fourteen out of eighteen starts, crashed through with a double victory over the Newark Bears today, 4 to 2 and 7 to 5, to dislodge their neighborhood rivals from second place in the International League before a crowd of 6,917.
Two thousand children and their parents joined in the eighth annual Independence Day celebration held yesterday under the auspices of the Home Thrift Association Children's Center.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP)-- The West Coast marine strike was canceled today, two and a half hours after the midnight deadline which was to have sent C.I.O. marine cooks and stewards to the picket lines to blockade 175 American flag ships.

ROME, July 4--No sign was given here today to show that the Italian Navy or Air Force had tried to prevent the British from seizing or sinking the French Fleet. Today's war bulletin, which covers developments until last midnight, says nothing about the action.

The force of the bomb explosion was felt in every part of the Fair's 1,260 acres, but the festive holiday crowd regarded it as just another Fourth of July aerial bomb such as were exploded around the Fair grounds all afternoon.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP)--The faststarting Pass Out from Robert W. Daniel's Brandon Farm in Virginia set the pace for seven rival 3-yearolds and hung on just long enough to nose out the Dixiana Farm's Sirocco today in the sixth running of the $15,000-added Yankee Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

PANAMA, July 4--Members of the American colony and their good neighbors of Panama celebrated the Fourth of July here today, assisted by the Army and Navy forces stationed at the Canal Zone.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, July 4--North and South America were drawn closer together by the wings of commerce today when the PanAmerican Airways clipper Rainbow landed here after a six-hour flight from Miami to complete the first non-stop commercial flight ever ...

WASHINGTON, July 4--Announcement of extensive amplification of the government's information service on manufacturers' inventories, new and unfilled orders, and shipments was made today by Edward J. Noble, Under-Secretary of Commerce.
The twenty-fourth ordinary annual general meeting of the Venezuelan Oil Concessions, Ltd., was held on Tuesday, June 18th, at Winchester House, Old Broadstreet, London, E.C., England.

LONDON, July 4--The Air Ministry described today how a Sunderland flying boat of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command found the sinking prison ship Arandora Star northwest of Ireland with hundreds of survivors clinging to rafts all around her.

OTTAWA, July 4--A milling crowd jamming the corridors of the Canadian Passport Office today made that branch of the Department of External Affairs look more like the outside of the turnstiles at a baseball game than an offshoot of government.
Hostesses who have large dinner parties on the schedule some time during this long holiday week-end apparently can do no better than get a big turkey for the main course.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4-- With the firing of twenty-two guns, 173 craft were started today in the fifty-ninth Independence Day regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The first contingent of mature men, of an average age of 35 years, willing to leave important civilian positions and pay the government for a month of military training, left the Grand Central Terminal quietly last night on a special train for Plattsburg Barracks.

The Brooklyn Red Cross Chapter passed its original $200,000 goal yesterday while a $5,000 contribution by J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., and other donations raised the war relief fund of the New York Chapter to $1,616,372, which was still nearly $400,000 short of its minimum quota ...

WASHINGTON, July 4--Most of the President's tax proposals have been as sudden and unexpected as they have been radical. Twice they have upset plans for the adjournment of Congress in which he had appeared to acquiesce.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4-- Ida Lupino will play the feminine lead opposite John Garfield in Warners' "Fiesta in Manhattan," the studio announced today.

BERLIN, July 4--The French Government or Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today communicated to William C. Bullitt, the United States Ambassador, an "indignant" protest against Britain's naval attack on French warships at Oran, Algeria, German dispatches said.

Officials of the Public Works Administration is Washington have instructed Colonel M.E. Gilmore, regional PWA director here, to hold up grants totaling $5,039,440 on four uncompleted projects in this city, PWA representatives disclosed yesterday.

Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons yesterday that the major part of the French Fleet either had joined the British, had been bottled up in British-held ports or had been destroyed in Wednesday's unprecedented naval actions between the two former Allies. The rest will be hunted down to keep them from falling into German or Italian hands.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, July 2 (delayed)--Among the formidable problems with which the French Government is grappling in the midst of difficulties is a complete reorganization of finances and the costs of repatriation and demobilization.

VALHALLA, N.Y., July 4--Angered by the refusal of his daughter, Melba Moshell, 15 years old, to leave a boarding school here and return to his home, Joseph Moshell, 47, of 252 East Girard Avenue, Philadelphia, visited the school this afternoon and shot and killed the girl, according to the State Police.

WESTKILL, N.Y., July 4--We deserted the bass fishing this morn ing in favor of the Schoharie trout, for the rain seems to have put the bass off their feed. Either that, or they are too full of natural food to show much interest in artificials.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP)--The White Sox took a double-header with the Browns today, the first game by 7 to 3 and the second by 8 to 5, before a crowd of 19,519.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 4--Lawn tennis in the metropolitan area burgeoned from mediocrity to brilliance today with the gathering at the Nassau Country Club of the finest field to compete here in years for the Challenge Bowl.

ROSEMONT, Pa., July 4--The Rev. and Mrs. William P.S. Lander of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Barbara Lander, to Frederick Lownes Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Wilson of Watertown, Conn.

ANDOVER, N.J., July 4--The arrest of three leaders of the German-American Bund put a damper on the Independence Day celebration this afternoon at Camp Nordland, the recreation center here of the New Jersey unit.

DETROIT, July 4--The Indians lost, then regained the American League lead today by splitting a double-header with the Tigers before a roaring crowd of 57,633, largest ever to see a baseball game at Briggs Stadium.
BERLIN, July 4 (UP)--The German High Command today reported the torpedoing of a third British aircraft carrier, the Illustrious.

Stock Exchange was closed in observance of Independence Day. Last quotation for call loans was 1 per cent; maturity money, 1 @l per cent for near and distant dates; @ 5/8 per cent for prime name commercial paper; bankers' bills, thirty to ninety days, bid, offered at seven-sixteenths of 1 per cent discount.

PARIS, July 2 (Delayed; via Berlin)--Paris is threatened with a second invasion--that of its returning refugees, who are crowding every road leading back to the city from the south and whose coming will seriously worsen the former capital's food problem.

LOOKING backward, many of the fight fans are referring to a recent event as a striking example of Jersey justice. Without too much formality, a certain gent got all that was coming to him. And in a hurry.
TOKYO, July 4--British residents of Japan are ready for a sudden departure. A break with Japan for the first time in British history begins to appear a probability rather than a possibility.

The city's vocational schools will set in motion on Monday a $1,000,000 program of training 10,000 technicians for national defense, it was announced yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.
YONKERS, N.Y., July 4--Mrs. Edith Elting Pattou, author of "Causeries en France" and other phrase books for the use of travelers, today died in St. John's Hospital after being ill for a year.

The First National Bank in St. Louis, Mo., reported yesterday as of June 29 total deposits of $260,999,650 and total assets of $281,769,088 compared, respectively, with $258,174,945 and $280,082,049 on March 26.

AMSTERDAM, July 4--New regulations for the Bourse were published today, indicating early reopening of the Exchange. Securities are to be divided into two groups: "daily quoted" and "unofficial trade without quotation."

CHICAGO, July 4--Advocator, entry of Charles S. Howard of San Francisco, going to the post at even money, ran to a handy triumph in the $10,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap before a holiday throng of nearly 50,000 at Arlington Park today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 4-- King Carol appointed a strongly pro-German, anti-Semitic Cabinet today and embarked the country firmly on the course of totalitarian rule, in which the leader principle will replace parliamentarianism.

Winston Churchill was understating when he said yesterday that the disposition of the French Navy was a "grim and somber" problem. It was, on sentimental grounds alone, the most heartbreaking choice that ever confronted a British Government.

A new secular cantata, "This Is Our Time," by William Schuman, with text by the poet, Genevieve Taggard, was the featured offering at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, last night in Lewisohn Stadium before an audience estimated at 6,000.

The expansion of American war exports to England and France since last September, and the increase in exports to non-European neutrals, have hitherto largely concealed the less favorable effects of the war upon American foreign trade as a whole.

BOSTON, July 4--The roar of Yankee artillery echoed over the Common today in a peacetime entertainment that saw the American League champions win a doubleheader from the Red Sox before a gathering of 29,000.

LENOX, Mass., July 4--With thermometers registering 60, the great fireplace at the Lenox Club was ablaze with cord-wood today during the seventy-sixth annual Fourth of July luncheon.

Net income of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company for the first live months of this year amounted to $498,477 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the report issued yesterday.

GIBRALTAR, July 5--Gibraltar had its first air raid of the war early this morning. A raider was first heard at 1:45 A.M., when searchlights picked it up. It was last seen four hours later when it made a low-dive attack on the harbor, dropping eight bombs, all of which fell into the sea.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 5-- After being in a collision and having her mizzen mast and the sail that gent with it carried away, Henry C. Taylor's yawl Baruna, winner of the recent ocean race, carried on in the regatta today off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, and with only her mainsail and large jib set won out in the large Handicap Class division.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 5--The Nassau Country Club Challenge Bowl, in competition since 1913, was preserved for at least another year of competition today with the defeat of Gilbert Hunt of Washington, D.C., winner of the invitation tennis tournament here in 1937 and 1938.

Eugene Barrera, principal research psychiatrist at the institute, reported yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 5-- Compared with the atmosphere of the past ten days, tranquillity reigned tonight in Rumania. That is purely a relative state. Whether it will last and how long is speculative.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 5-- In line with her efforts to buttress her military conquests by the consolidation of her political supremacy on the European Continent which has already resulted in Rumania's adherence to the Rome-Berlin Axis, Germany has also taken steps to coordinate Scandinavia in the new European order and the results of two such steps were revealed today.

Fordham University initiated the twenty-third annual session of its Summer school yesterday with a registration of 1,650, an enrollment increase of 10 per cent over last year's 1,500 attendance. It is the fifth consecutive year that the university's Summer session has shown an increase.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The time will come reasonably soon, unless meanwhile and miraculously the Nazi regime is overthrown, when a compact program for national security must come up for discussion as a counterproposal to the "hemisphere defense" idea.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Five recommendations on trial procedure by the Federal Trade Commission were made here today by I.W. Digges, counsel for the Association of National Advertisers, in testimony before the Attorney General's Committee on Administrative Procedure ...

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)--Despite prospects of reduced crops of corn, tobacco, wheat, rye and some fruits, the Department of Agriculture reported today that conditions on July 1 indicated that the nation would have ample supplies of most major farm products for the coming season.

Sickle T., winner of seven races and almost $28,000 last year, scored his first 1940 victory yesterday at Empire City, where he was the even-money choice in the Gramatan Handicap and won because of the skill of Ronnie Nash. The margin was a length at the end of a mile and a furlong, but Nash saved ...
BERLIN, July 10--The presence of British warships about Martinique has been the subject of considerable cynical comment by the German press.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate approved today, with a few minor changes, after only a few minutes of debate and without a record vote, the House bill authorizing a "two-ocean" navy by 1946.

CHICAGO, July 10--What little doubt remained here that President Roosevelt would accept a thirdterm nomination from the Democratic National Convention next week, or that he would have any trouble whatever in getting it, was narrowed still further by two events here today.
