Both official accounts of the BritishItalian naval battle claim that the enemy ships retired. That may be; it takes time to check on engagements fought in the wide fields of the open sea. But the smoke is not thick enough to obscure the far-reaching importance of this first encounter of the only two fleets of any consequence now at large in European waters.

A leading faculty member of Teachers College told 1,000 teachers from all parts of the nation yesterday that for years they had been preaching fallacies about war, peace and America's role in the world.

A season of careful management has apparently established the World's Fair as a successful day-to-day business enterprise. Mr. Harvey Gibson, chairman of the board, reports net earnings for the first fifty-eight days of operation as $696,118, with no deferred indebtedness and every prospect of improving business for the rest of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Designation of the Vanderbilt mansion, north of Hyde Park, in Dutchess County, as a national historic site, and the appointment of Mrs. Dexter Cooper of New York City as superintendent, were announced today by Secretary Ickes.

ROME, July 10--The first step in the construction of "the new order in Europe" which is being taken in Munich today and tomorrow will not yet be a decisive one, according to well-informed circles here.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)--Miss Patty Berg, a determined miss who took 122 strokes on her first round of golf eight years ago--including a penalty for teeing up her ball in a sandtrap--signed a four-figure contract to teach the game today.

LONDON, July 10 (Canadian Press)--Scores of names that have appeared in the war news were re peated tonight in the military section of the King's birthday honors list as King George bestowed awards for meritorious service and bravery.

BERLIN, July 10 -- Chancellor Hitler at Munich this morning received Count Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, Count Paul Teleki and Count Stephen Csaky, Premier and Foreign Minister, respectively, of Hungary, and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 10-- Following is the text of the introduction of the resolution prepared by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval, Premier and Vice Premier, and voted on by the French Parliament at Vichy today to place France under a dictatorship:
LONDON, July 10--An expansion of the British Purchasing Commission in the United States, both in personnel and power, is expected to take place soon.

Officials of ten municipal housing authorities sold yesterday $31,137,000 of notes maturing in six months. Of the total, a banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company bought $26,010,000 at 0.57 per cent and the balance of $5,127,000 went to other firms.
A new international unit, which will fly the flags of all countries represented at the World's Fair, will open Saturday on Constitution Mall, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The House by a vote of 243 to 122 passed today the Hatch bill to extend the prohibition against pernicious political activities to State employes paid wholly or in part from Federal funds.

The entire European continent, with a few exceptions, was described yesterday as "a vast concentration camp" by Morris C. Troper, European chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, who arrived on the Yankee Clipper to discuss readjustment of the relief program to meet new needs.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (AP)-- Governmental control over the uses which may be made of property abutting on arterial highways and official supervision of the architecture of all future buildings were advocated today before the National Conference on Planning.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 10-- Charles E. Finlay, real estate developer and founder and president for eight years of the Aetna National Bank until it merged with the Irving Trust Company, died today at Kenwood, his home here, after a brief illness. His age was 78.

CHICAGO, July 10--Fair trade laws pased by forty-two States have resulted in a 1 per cent reduction in the average retail prices of goods sold under these laws through retail drug stores, the National Association of Retail Druggists announced today in making public the details of a recently completed survey by the druggists' research bureau.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation last month totaled 1,209,684 net tons, the highest for the year, compared with 1,084,057 tons in the previous month and with 807,562 tons in the same month last year. The figure is the highest since 1,443,969 tons shipped in December, 1939.

LONDON, July 10 (AP)--The British press and public exhibited satisfaction today over the appointment of the Duke of Windsor as Governor and Commander in Chief of the Bahamas. Most Britons saw their former King in the role of goodwill ambassador to the New World.

Midyear changes in officers and directorships, in addition to those that were made known on the preceding day, were announced yesterday by several banks in this city, following regular meetings of the boards of directors. In each instance the election was to fill a vacancy.

SHANGHAI, July 10--The Japanese Navy today formally joined in anti-American denunciations and the Japanese Embassy spokesman made it plain that the Japanese authorities were doing nothing to curb the civilian anti-American campaign in Shanghai.

With less July liquidation and unfavorable official and private crop reports from several States, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 9 to 17 points yesterday in light trading. Better prices in Liverpool and Bombay and the fact that only new-style contracts will be in force after midday next Wednesday helped steady the market.
COLORADO SPRINGS, July 10-- Relieved for a time from the pressure of campaign planning, Wendell L. Willkie spent the first day of his vacation here "just loafing."

"Boys and Girls Together" is the new title for the Ed Wynn musical, which was known for a while as "The Funnies." Boston will see it for two weeks, beginning Labor Day, and Philadelphia for a similar period before it arrives on Broadway early in October.

LONDON, July 10--Parliament today received a bill to strengthen the hand of the authorities in dealing with subversive elements. A bill introduced today amends the Defense Act of 1939 to make civilians subject to court martial.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10 (AP)-- Mike Chartak, Newark outfielder, clouted three home runs tonight, his twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth, to bring the Bears a 6-5 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs. Chartak's third circuit blow of the game, in the eighth inning with the bases empty, broke a tie and settled the see-saw battle.

Local journals have told how The Great White Father of Heat-Stricken Heath gave over to dolor and sadness a month ago or so when thunder rolled and rumbled over Trylon and Perisphere; when convulsive clouds poured darkly over Flushing horizon and left The Meadow deep in rain.

CHICAGO, July 10--Action of the wheat market today was similar to that in recent sessions. An early bulge on unfavorable crop comments from the Northwest was followed by a reaction of around 1 cents a bushel from the top, owing to increased hedging sales. Short covering later in the session by traders who were evening up for ...
A spectacular fire roared through a six-story loft building early this morning at 209 West Forty-eighth Street, just west of Broadway and Times Square, in the theatrical area known as Tin Pan Alley.

Dr. Frank P. Corrigan, United States Ambassador to Venezuela, has been joined at Essex House by Mrs. Corrigan and their sons-in-law and daughters, Mr. and Mrs. Archer Berry Hannah of San Salvador and Dr. and Mrs. Albert Earl Pappano ...
LONDON, July 10--The government took drastic steps today toward perfecting its defenses against enemies at home as well as abroad.

ST. LOUIS, July 10--The 1940 AllStar game melted quietly into oblivion today. By late afternoon nearly all the out-of-town participants in yesterday's struggle which saw the National League forces heap a humiliating 4-to-0 defeat upon their American League rivals ...

One of the largest realty deals on Washington Heights in some time was closed yesterday when the two apartment buildings at 884 and 894 Riverside Drive were sold by the builders, the Melvin Construction ...

The United States liner Washington, which went to Galway on a special emergency voyage to bring American citizens out of the war zones, is nearing the American side of the Atlantic and is expected to reach her West Eighteenth Street ...

WEST HARWICH, Mass., July 10--Dr. Joseph W. Schereschewsky, noted cancer specialist and founder of the Cancer Research Center at Harvard University and of a research center in Georgia for the United States Public Health Service, died yesterday at his Summer home here after a heart attack. His age was 67.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers, Goldman, Sachs Co. and the First Boston Corporation will offer today $32,000,000 of Indianapolis Power and Light Company first mortgage 3 per cent bonds due in 1970. The bonds, dated May 1, 1940, and due on May 1, 1970, will be priced at 104 and accrued interest.

LONDON, July 10 (AP)--Admiral Sir Richard Henry Peirse, retired, who commanded the Allied naval forces on the Suez Canal for the first two years of the World War, died today at his home near Bath. He was 79 years old. He was aidede-camp to King Edward VII in 1908 and 1909.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., July 10-- An epic flight in a stolen airplane by two Long Island boys, who were determined to get to Canada by hook or crook to join the Royal Air Force, ended today when the plane crashed through apple trees and into a cow pasture in northern Westchester County.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 10-- Six rounds were completed in the second annual chess masters tournament at the Municipal Pier today, when four adjourned games were played off, and thus the halfway mark was passed. The final is scheduled for Saturday night.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 10--"Hard work" was advocated today as the best method by which women might win high posts in business and professional life. Opinions were advanced at the biennial meeting of the executive board of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs here.

As a preliminary to the Lew Jenkins-Henry Armstrong non-title twelve-rounder at the Polo Grounds next Wednesday, the respective managers of the two fighters have been doing some fast shadow boxing themselves.

Yesterday was a hot Summer's day, the official thermometer read 87 degrees at 4:30 o'clock in the afternoon and 88 at 7 P.M., but it was remarkable only because the long expected seemed at last to have arrived. The Rockaways experienced their largest weekday crowds of the year, and other ...

Belief that her mental condition was incurable caused a 43-year-old mother, in the absence of her husband, to kill her six children and to seek to end her life yesterday morning by turning on five gas jets in her three-room flat at 2434 Eastchester Road, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)--Several House members were waiting tonight for an explanation from Representative Collins of Mississippi of the circumstances surrounding the showing on Capitol Hill of what Representative O'Toole of New York called a "terror" motion picture of German conquest in Europe.

In an order unprecedented in the history of the Police Department, all detectives of the city who are not on sick leave, vacation or urgent duty were directed yesterday to report this morning at the police line-up at Manhattan headquarters.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 10In a stormy session of the French Parliament at Vichy today, the defenders of France's doomed democratic rule forced the Petain Government, in their last defiant stand, to agree that the nation's new totalitarian dictatorship would be placed before the people in a national plebiscite.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 10-- Charley Whitehead, State amateur golf champion, switched to his old partner Johnny Kinder, Plainfield Country Club professional, today and won the pro-amateur prelude to the New Jersey State open championship with a seven-under-par 65.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 10--Injury again struck at the Dodgers' pennant hopes when Hugh Casey, star right-handed pitcher, was hit on the head with a pitched ball in an exhibtion game tonight and remained in Mercy Hospital under the care of Dr. James Murray as his team-mates departed for Cincinnati. The extent of his injury will not be known for twenty-four hours.

The first group in New York City's defense program for the training of skilled workers, numbering 400 men and representing such diverse occupations as night watchmen, apartment house superintendents and garage mechanics, began work yesterday in the shops of Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn ...

WASHINGTON, July 10--Communist party opposition to a bill approved in the House requiring registration of and detailed data on "foreign-controlled" organizations was voiced before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today by Earl Browder, the party's general ...

A CURIOUS Chinese document, half adult, A half juvenile in spirit and purpose, is published this morning under the title of "Girl Rebel: The Autobiography of Hsieh Pingying." The translation is the work of Lin Yutang's daughters, Adet, aged 16, and Anor, aged 13.

The age limit for young men enrolling in the four months' naval training course established recently by President Roosevelt to provide ensigns for the Navy's fast growing fleet of fighting ships has been broadened to include persons between 18 and 27 years old, it was ...

VALLETTA, Malta, July 10-- Three Italian planes were shot down by anti-aircraft fire and British fighters today in a raid on Malta, the British reported. A fourth machine was so badly damaged that it was not likely that it could reach its base.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., July 10--The Civilian Aeronautic Authority's student pilot-training program at this field, part of the government's plan for strengthening the air defense, was brought to a standstill today by an order from the airport management forbidding further training in "light planes."

WASHINGTON, July 10--Great Britain has suggested to the United States the pooling of British resources involving war materials and other commodities essential for prosecuting the war with the resources of the Americas.

LONDON, Thursday, July 11--One of the most spectacular air battles of the war thus far, with a hundred or more planes engaged, raged off the Channel coast yesterday. Big formations of British and German planes came to the death grip after Nazi airmen had attempted to attack a convoy.

Henri Bernstein, noted French dramatist, who arrived here on Monday, a refugee from his country, declared yesterday in an interview that any hope the French people may have for a peace tempered with mercy from Germany will prove illusory.

Except for a slight flurry among the public utility issues, the stock market followed yesterday its "pinpoint" pattern, while there was a further slackening of trading interest. Even the moderately quickened activity in the bond section on Tuesday was absent.

Barring the possibility of the defeat of the British on England's soil, the United States appears headed for very active business during the remainder of this year, John Block of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, said last night at the Fall Fashion Forum put on by his organization at the BarbizonPlaza Hotel.

CHICAGO, July 10--Dr. Austin Albert Hayden, secretary of the board of trustees of the American Medical Association and an authority on deafness and hearing devices, died here today in St. Joseph's Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 58. He had been in poor health for a month.

SPRING LAKE, N.Y., July 10-- The arrival on the scene of Frank Parker and Gardnar Mulloy and the exit of Wilmer Allison, former national champion, were the developments of major interest in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club today as the field moved into the quarter-finals.

Eight persons were sent to hospitals and 101 others were less severely injured when a White Plains commuters' train, crowded with 900 passengers, ran into the bumper at the end of track 110 on the lower level of the Grand Central Terminal at 8:24 o'clock yesterday morning.
OTTAWA, July 10--While the Canadian Parliament has been debating higher taxes, its Department of Munitions has been actually spending those taxes faster than Parliament can vote them.

WASHINGTON, July 10--A trainload of children's food, contributed by the American Red Cross through tha League of Red Cross Societies, is en route from Geneva, Switzerland, to the part of France unoccupied by invaders for distribution to needy children, the Red Cross headquarters said today.

THE life of the party at St. Louis was Bobo Newsom from Hartsville, S.C. This husky and hilarious hurler is having a great year and nobody could blame him for not keeping quiet about it. He hasn't lost a ball game since the opening day of the season. Bobo is one of the big reasons why the Tigers are now leading the American League parade.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Allison Wright Post of White Lodge, this place, and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Alice Post Fahnestock of Brookline, Mass., and New York, to Robert J. Hare Powel of Newport, R.I.

Only a few weeks ago the President said he saw no reason, vital to national defense, for holding Congress in session throughout the Summer months, except for the "laudable" purpose of making speeches.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 10 (AP)-- Spencer Scott, owned by C.W. Phillis of Greenwich, Conn., and driven by the veteran Fred Egan, captured the $4,427 Matron Stake in three straight heats of the Grand Circuit's feature event tonight.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Riccardo Salmona entertained with a dinner with dancing tonight at Canoe Place Inn for Mrs. Salmona's daughter, Miss Patricia Kane O'Connell, to celebrate her birthday. Among the guests were the Misses Edith Beadleston, Hazel Farr, Anne Hoffman, Barbara ...

LONDON, July 10--The AngloItalian naval action of yesterday is described by the British commander in chief in the Mediterranean, Sir Andrew Cunningham, as "disappointing," the Admiralty announced tonight.

With international yacht racing out of the picture indefinitely, plans for a novel intersectional series between the Seawanhaka Corinthian and the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., are being discussed, it was announced yesterday by Philip J. Roosevelt, Commodore of the Long Island Club.

LOS ANGELES, July 10 (AP)-- Herbert Hoehne, a German traveler arrested with consular dispatches to the Reich's Latin-American lega tions in his possession, was indicted today as a foreign agent.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 10 (AP)-- Military preparations were speeded in Turkey tonight following a call by the government for an emergency session of the National Assembly Friday to consider demands Russia is expected to make on Turkey.

ROME, July 10--The Pope today urged Germany and Italy to abstain from taking revenge on France and to conclude a fair peace. Clemency alone, he said, can prevent the fostering of the hatred that inevitably follows the imposition of harsh terms on the vanquished.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10--An injury broke up the promising young doubles team of Miss Dorothy Wightman and Miss Margaret Madden of Boston today in the quarter-final round of the Middle States women's tennis tournament.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 10--Gordon Claus, 20year-old player from the Midvale Club in the Rochester district, today was top qualifier among the fifty-two competing in the tenth annual junior championship of the New York State Golf Association.
ALBANY, July 10--The 8,934 stock corporations formed in the State in the first six months of this year were 303 more than in the corresponding period of 1939, Secretary of State Walsh reported today.

ALBANY, July 10--The State now holds under the joint custody of Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, and Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, $559,553,122 in bonds and other securities, the officials announced today.

MEMPHIS, July 10--A movement to draft Kenneth G. Crawford for another term as unpaid president of the American Newspaper Guild was discussed informally by some Guild convention delegates today, despite statements by Mr. Crawford that he would not be a candidate.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The Treasury offered today $600,000,000 of 2 per cent bonds of 1954-56, which is the longest term Treasury issue since it sold $894,000,000 of 22-27 year bonds on March 15, last year.

A rather disturbing story about a gray fox comes from Mr. William H. Carr, well and favorably known to nature lovers as the director of the Trailside Museum at Bear Mountain. AUSTIN, Texas, July 10 (AP)-- Chairman Martin Dies of the House committee to investigate un-American activities, said today that he had information that a plot to sabotage a battleship under construction in a Pennsylvania navy yard had been uncovered.

EDGEWATER, N.J., July 10-- Captain John J. McCabe, who is serving his thirty-fourth year as a skipper of ferry boats between 125th Street and Edgewater, made his 250,000th trip at 11 o'clock this morning and received a commorative plaque from the owners of the Palisades Amusement Park.

LONDON, July 10--A diplomatic report that could not be confirmed in official British quarters circulated in London today to the effect that Soviet Russia had asked Iran for a strip of territory along the Soviet-Iran border.

WILTON, Conn., July 10--More than 500 residents of this town assembled tonight in town meeting and organized the Wilton Committee for National Defense as the first of what the sponsors hoped might be a nation-wide network of local organizations backing a national preparedness program.

The difficulties faced by democratic governments in financing war expenditures are being well illustrated today in Great Britain. It has not been possible there to prevent rising prices. Edwin McArthur conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the third and last time this season last night at Lewisohn Stadium. As on the previous evening, Mr. McArthur devoted the first half of the program to works by American composers.

Postcards urging a "Chicago Draft Roosevelt Parade" have been sent out by the Citizens Draft Roosevelt Parade Committee, at 475 Fifth Avenue. Investigation at that address yesterday showed the sponsor of the move to be Daniel W. Blumenthal, prominent Democratic ...

The Federal indictment of the American Pulpwood Association and twelve corporations, made public here last Friday, was attacked yesterday by two members of the industry. H.E. Brinckerhoff, secretary of the association, declared that the indictment was "wholly unwarranted."
LONDON, July 10--The evacuation of British childrer to the United States and the dominions has been postponed, or at least greatly curtailed.

It now appears that Dick Reed of Maine may don the scaled mantle of the Order of Fish Prophets, for his prediction on giant tuna hitting near Bailey Island this week has been justified. Frank Ludermann of New York City brought in a 479-pounder, the first bluefin of the season for that port.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 10 (AP)--Rhode Island's celebrated golfing sisters, the Misses Helen and Bette Waterhouse, today shot their way through the second round of the Shenecossett women's invitation tournament and into a meeting in the semi-final round.
Irving Berlin has established a trust fund for all royalties from his song hit "God Bless America"; which are to be used among the youth of America for patriotic purposes, it was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10-- Gregory Ratoff today signed with Paramount to produce and direct "Ballerina," by Lady Eleanor Smith, with Loretta Young as the star. Ratoff had acquired Lady Eleanor's novel last February while he was at Fox, announcing at that ...

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10-- Dr. Alfred Rosenberg's speech in which he blandly annexed all Scandinavia, including Sweden, to a Pan-Germanic and put it under the "protection" of the Reich was read in Sweden today with emotion that ranged from amazement and boiling rage to disdainful irony.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10-- After an Odyssey of nearly three months and incidents that included seizure and bombing, a Swedish armada of four destroyers purchased from Italy before the war, arrived with their two supply ships at Goeteborg today.

WASHINGTON, July 10--President Roosevelt asked Congress in a special message today for another $4,848,171,957 for further expansion of the military and naval for ces under a program of total defense against a total war, but pledged that this country would not send a man to take part in Europe's wars.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 11 (UP)-- Japan pressed her demands against Britain today and was reported to have informed the British they must give a pledge to stop shipments to Nationalist China through British-controlled territories "in the very near future or suffer the consequences."

Mr. Willkie has shown sound judgment by selecting as chairman of the National Republican Committee another man of sound judgment, Representative Joseph William Martin Jr. of Massachusetts. A resolution urging that the Army, Navy and other air forces of the Federal Government be formed into a combined air force under a unified command will be presented to the New York County organization of the American Legion tonight at the closing meeting of its twenty-second annual convention.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, July 10--Both the Japanese steamship Brasil Maru, carrying the Brazilian delegation to the Havana conference, and the Uruguay, with the Argentine delegation, sailed today for Santiago, from where the delegates will entrain for Havana.

The submarine ball offerings of Elden Auker were sunk without a trace yesterday as the Yankees exploded ten hits for twenty bases to beat the Browns, 6--4, at the Stadium in opening their critical home stand against the West.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The Republican Advisory Committee, headed by Governor Stassen of Minnesota, a new agency in Republican politics, met here today with Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the National Committee, and Senator McNary, Vice-Presidential nominee, and mapped out plans for the campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The Senate accepted today the House amendments to the Hatch bill to extend the "Clean Politics" Act to State employes paid wholly or partially from Federal funds and sent the legislation to the White House.

Lew Henderson, wildlife artist and sportsman, has just returned from a bass fishing trip to the St. Lawrence, and his report is far from encouraging. There seem to be plenty of small bass, but most of them are just about "keeper" size.

In an extraordinary bit of police procedure Commissioner Valentine yesterday assembled 675 detectives in a pep meeting at which he exhorted them to find the persons responsible for the July 4 bombing and warned that other bombs might be expected.

BERLIN, July 11 (AP)--All American ambulance drivers known to be in German hands are to be freed promptly, some after trying experiences, the German High Command informed the United States Embassy today.
The President's message of Wednesday was not merely a request for huge new appropriations for defense. In it the President stressed his own record on the defense issue.

TOKYO, July 11--Indications of an impending political change are widespread. The newspaper Asahi says that although the curtain is still down the stage is set and developments will be rapid after Prince Fumimaro Konoye's return from the country on Sunday.
BERLIN, July 11--President Roosevelt's message to Congress was received in Berlin today "in a manner which has now become customary for American declarations."

Failure of weather in eastern sections of the Cotton Belt to clear, with showers persisting in parts of Alabama and Georgia more than a week, caused yesterday a further improvement in new-crop months on the Cotton Exchange.

With Archduke Otto of Habsburg, pretender to the non-existent Austro-Hungarian throne; Madeleine Carroll, English motion picture star, and fifteen other passengers fleeing the war, the Atlantic Clipper of Pan American Airways arrived at La Guardia Field at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 11-- German diplomatic agents and commercial representatives throughout South America have combined to bring heavy diplomatic and commercial pressure on the South American counrties on the eve of the Havana conference.

CHICAGO, July 11--To an observer new-come to this scene of next week's Democratic National Convention there is one sign of contest, already visible in what otherwise is forecast as a ratification meeting.

Existing scarcities of many French wines and brandies and the certainty that supplies will be cut off indefinitely by the British blockade combined to bring an upward surge in prices in the wholesale market this week. Retailers here complained that there was no uniformity to many of the advances and that jobbers were charging "whatever the traffic will bear."

Aviation Building bar and grill hands out cash register receipts with all drinks. This is apt to puzzle pilgrims from afar. The other day a grave, ham-fisted Western gentleman stared at the receipt that came to him with 15 cents change when he put down 25 cents for a beer.

The contrast between the famous "Munich" of 1938 and the latest meeting at Munich constitutes an ironic commentary on the logic of history as it is now written. NORTH CONWAY, N.H., July 12--Another masterful performance by Seymour Greenberg for his second surprise victory in as many days enabled the 19-year-old Chicagoan to square accounts with George Toley this afternoon and reach the Eastern Slope gold racquet tennis final.

WASHINGTON, July 12--From 70 to 100 P-40 pursuit planes destined for Great Britain are in storage at the Curtiss Aircraft Company plant in Buffalo because there are no engines for them, it was learned today.

Vagabond motorists who explore country roads these days are prepared for the antique, the quaint, the unusual, but sometimes they must stop and stare bewilderedly at youth on the hillsides. There they posture, gesticulate, dramatize. They leap and flutter in the ballet.

Hoppin for the Spouting Rock Beach Association was broken out to the breeze for the first time.

Perkins, chairman of the board of the National City Bank of New York and president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, will be held tomorrow at 4:30 P.M. at the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Perkins died suddenly after a heart attack Friday night at Mount Kisco.

REWARD: A German flier over England, his plane damaged, bailed out last week to land in the garden of Mrs. Daisy Cardwell, a farmer's wife. Mrs. Cardwell, local leader of the Women's Volunteer Service, rushed to him, ordered him to surrender. According to reports, he was armed, she was unarmed, yet he surrendered. King George gave Mrs. Cardwell the Medal of the Order of the British Empire.

When Napoleon III was Emperor of the French he used to visit the little provincial town of Vichy to drink its famous mineral waters. He made the town the best known of French spas. Summer became the fashionable season. Last week fashion was not prominent at Vichy.

WASHINGTON, July 14--A sketch of the operations of the Belgian Army which ended in its capitulation to Germany was issued today by the Belgian Embassy.
PITTSBURGH, July 14--That elusive 200th major league victory finally came to Freddy Fitzsimmons today.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 14-- Distribution of prizes today marked the close of the second annual invitation masters tournament of the Ventnor City Chess Club on the Municipal Pier. Play started on July 6 and ended last night.

PLATTSBURG, July 14--Clergymen of three religious faiths spoke today at the training camps here as more than 800 men in the business and professional men's training camp and almost 2,000 youths in the Citizens Military Training Camp had their first day of release from military duties.
OAKLAND, Calif., July 14 (AP)-- Thirteen years ago today a fragile little two-place plane droned uncertainly through stormy skies to complete the first civilian flight from this continent to Hawaii.

A suit to enjoin the city from using any part of the revenue, of the occupancy tax for any other purpose than municipal housing subsidies was started in Supreme Court Saturday by Mrs. Helen C. Wilmerding of 12 East Eightyninth Street, it was learned yesterday.

Maine Coast waters are providing considerable sport for deep-sea fishermen now. The State Development Commission announced yesterday that tuna are coming in great schools and that their early arrival, one week ahead of schedule, has caught the rod and reel men by surprise.

CHICAGO, July 14--The Chicago Stadium, ready for the opening at noon tomorrow of the twenty-eighth Democratic National Convention, is a canvas of color inside and out, with bright red predominating within. COLORADO SPRINGS, July 14-- Wendell L. Willkie, Republican Presidential nominee, attended an old-fashioned fish fry this afternoon at Almont, a four-house hamlet on the banks of the Gunnison River.

CHICAGO, July 14--The ascendancy of the Democratic male would seem, from a quick survey in crowded hotel lobbies here, to be hovering in political twilight. Women visitors with warm opinions on issues and candidates seem to outnumber men by four to one. This ratio of women to men is greater than it was at the Republican convention in Philadelphia.

THERE'S always something new. Over-theweight bouts in boxing are common enough when champions wish to cash in on their reputations without putting their crowns in peril. CHICAGO, July 14--Price trends in the Sears Roebuck Co. Two New York millinery designers opened fashion shows yesterday to show Fall styles in women's hats. John-Frederics presented a collection of new styles at 29 East Forty-eighth Street and Florence Reichman opened a show at 18 East Fifty-second Street.

Willikie, Republican Presidential nominee.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 17--Chile has a sixth column as well as a fifth. It is the League of Defence, composed of thousands of youths of all classes and all parties from Socialists to extreme Rightists.

CHICAGO, July 17--After a long delay due to differences of opinion among members of the committee on resolutions on the foreign relations plank, Senator Wagner of New York, chairman of the committee, presented the final draft of the platform to the Democratic convention tonight. It was adopted by a voice vote.

The Montana, a seven-story elevator apartment house at the southwest corner of West 124th Street and Nathan Davis Place, in Harlem, has been sold by Henry Lichtig, trustee, to a syndicate headed by Maceep S. Maloof. The transfer was the first involving the property in twenty years and was made on an all-cash basis.

LONDON, July 17--Amid a lull in German air-raids on this country and British raids on Germany, Air Secretary Sir Archibald Sinclair broadcast a warning today that Great Britain must expect air attacks on a scale many times greater than any yet launched by the Nazis, who, he admitted, still have numerical preponderance of air power.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP)--America's Ryder Cup golfers, undefeated since 1933, when they bowed before Great Britain's finest, turned back the challenge of Gene Sarazen's team today by breaking even in singles competition, thereby winning the two-day charity battle by a score of 7 to 5.

WASHINGTON, July 17--Federal engineers are studying the feasibility of a plan for a fourth major airport in the New York metropolitan district to be called the Atlantic Airport, which would be nearer than any of the others to lower Manhattan and would have direct facilities for transferring airplanes to ships docked alongside the landing field.

The broadcasting of the Democratic platform from the convention in Chicago last night drew violent protests from thousands of radio listeners here because it interfered with the scheduled broadcast of the fight between Henry Armstrong and Lew Jenkins at the Polo Grounds.

Something had to crack before hurling of such superlative skill, and as the shadows lengthened over the Stadium the Yankees caught up with the Indians' Boy Wonder. CHUNGKING, Thursday, July 18 --A formal statement by the Foreign Office spokesman condemns Britain's decision to close the Burma Road. The press and public joined in the clamor of denunciation.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 17 --It is learned in well-informed circles here that Germany is putting pressure on Rumania to resign from the Balkan Entente, which is considered more or less a bloc directed against the Axis and an instrument serving British and Russian interests.

LONDON, July 17--The Admiralty tonight completed the story of the Allied evacuation of Norway by announcing that German bombers sank the 13,241-ton British naval auxiliary Vandyck off the Norwegian coast on June 10. Two officers and five seamen were killed, and the rest of the crew, 29 officers and 132 seamen, were captured as prisoners of war.

A $2,300 contribution for ambulances was received yesterday from the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress for the war relief fund of the New York Red Cross Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue, which reached a total of $1,710,288. The chapter's quota for Manhattan and the Bronx is $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 20--The administration is studying the possibility of invoking its powers under the May Defense Expediting Act to curtail shipments of such raw materials as scrap iron to Japan.

THE American Red Cross announced recently that if everything goes as expected, by the first of September the knitters of America will have transformed 157,075 pounds of yarn into warm clothing for war refugees.

NICE, France, July 5--About six hours before the Franco-Italian armistice was signed, on the night of Sunday, June 23, the first real battle between those two countries occurred--the battle of Menton. ST. LOUIS, July 23--By now there can be no doubt of it. Night ball certainly is not for the Yankees. They played their fourth nocturnal game of the year against the Browns at Sportsman's Park before a gathering of 11,755 fans tonight and they lost their third straight under the incandescents besides dropping their fourth in a row.

The National League pennant race may have been settled in full view of 40,583 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, for the champion Reds toppled the Dodgers in both ends of a double-header, 4 to 3 and 9 to 2, the opener going eleven innings. Thus Cincinnati increased its league lead over Brooklyn to seven full games.

Justice Felix C. Benvenga in Supreme Court ruled yesterday that it was a violation of the State banking law for a small loans company to accept as a co-maker of a note a person already indebted to it for a loan. Such a violation, he also held, released the borrower from liability for both obligations.

CHICAGO, July 23--Traders in wheat were disposed to be cautious today, pending completion of liquidation in the July contract. Prices held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel. All deliveries sold at new seasonal low prices but rallied late in the session on local buying and short covering.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 24--Steel manufactured in Brazil, using 100 per cent Brazilian raw material, is on the eve of realization. Brazil aims to kill two birds with one stone in solving her steel problem, for the plan under way would keep the monopoly out of the hands of foreign elements and also realize a national dream more than 100 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29-- Charley R. Rogers announced today that he and Leopold Stokowski would make a picture late this Fall under the title "Serenade of Youth," in which Stokowski and his recently formed orchestra of musicians from 18 to 25 years old will appear.

Jules Romains, author of the monumental series of novels known as "Men of Good Will," who arrived from France two weeks ago, has settled in an apartment-hotel overlooking Central Park and has already started writing again.

Lieut, Col. Rutherford Ireland, New York National Guard (retired), veteran of the SpanishAmerican and World Wars and a retired insurance broker, died on Saturday at his residence, 36 Crooke Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 59.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 29-- Miss Mary Mullen Kelley, daughter of Edward F. Keller of this city, was married here this morning in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church to Edward Louis Cleary, son of Mrs. Robert Cleary of Naugatuck. Conn.

HONG KONG, July 29--China was reported today to have turned down unconditionally Japanese peace overtures giving Japan five northern Chinese provinces outright plus indirect hegemony over the Asiatic possessions of France and Britain.

SCHUYLER FALLS, N.Y., July 29--Pickett made a famous charge that failed to win the Battle of Gettysburg for his side. An unnamed hero in the Seventh Company of the Plattsburgers of 1940 started a charge that did not win the sham battle here today.

VICHY, France, July 29--A French Cabinet meeting this evening further discussed, according to a communique, the responsibility for "the passage from a state of peace to a state of war in September, 1939, and adopted a project of law creating a Supreme Court of Justice."

On the eve of the Senate debate on the Burke-Wadsworth bill for compulsory military training, the Gallup survey indicates that popular support for a measure of this kind is strong, and growing steadily.

LONDON, July 29--The British destroyer Wren has been bombed and sunk by German aircraft, the Admiralty announced today.
HOMEWOOD, III., July 29 (AP)-- Valdina Star, owned by Mrs. Joe Grossman, drove to victory in the featured Englewood Purse today as Washington Park opened its $450,000 meeting.

A welcome as warm as our July weather greeted the S.S. America yesterday as she came to her pier at the end of a first run. The welcome is more than local.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP)--Harry Jeffra of Baltimore successfully defended his newly won featherweight boxing crown tonight by punching out a decision over Spider Armstrong of Toronto in a fast and furious 15-round bout.

Arguments raged, tempers flared, fists flew arid base-hits crashed all over Ebbets Field yesterday in a tumultuous ninth inning. Finally the Dodgers took the measure of the Pirates, 7--6.
LA LINEA, Spain, July 29--Four British soldiers were reported killed and seven injured today in the explosion of an ammunition dump in Britain's great rock fortress at Gibraltar.

As the World's Fair's final season approached the half-way mark, which will be reached next weekend, and the administration prepared to start a final drive for attendance on many fronts, a survey of the crowd so far indicated yesterday a final total attendance of less than 16,000,000.

Frederic J. Fuller, a vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, 40 Wall Street, who had been prominent in banking and real estate in this city for twenty-five years, died yesterday at his residence, 1120 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of eight months. He was 57 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 29--The War Department today announced contracts totaling $17,096,222 for equipment and construction.
In the last four days, $54,000 in money and goods has been forwarded to Great Britain by the Allied Relief Fund, 57 William Street, in response to emergency requests for specific items.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29--There were several dinner parties tonight before the performance of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "Princess Ida," at Rogers High School Auditorium sung by the Swanhurst Choral Society of the Art Association.

LONDON, July 29--The stock markets showed today a marked absence of activity, the principal feature being fluctuations in home rail stocks due to disappointment over the small amount of business following the recent upward movement. Losses to 1 point were seen at the close.

WASHINGTON, July 29--President Roosevelt asked Congress today for prompt action on legislation to permit him to order out the National Guard for a year's training, and for possible service in the Western Hemisphere and the Territories and possessions of the United States, including the Philippine Islands.

HANOVER, N.H., July 29--Dr. Ashley K. Hardy, professor of German and senior member of the Dartmouth College faculty, died here today at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital following a heart attack suffered four weeks ago. He was 69 years old.

ST. LOUIS, July 29--An enthusiastic demonstration for President Roosevelt by delegates to the convention of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers of America today set at rest earlier reports that a floor fight might develop against the endorsement of the President for a third term which had been voted by the union's general executive board.

The second shipment of gold from the Assay Office in Old Slip to the Government's storage vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., went forward last night. The procedure employed when the first shipment was made last Thursday again was resorted to yesterday.

After twelve days of "crusading" the American Women's Committee for the Release of Ships for European Children, headed by Mrs. Auguste Richard and Mrs. Harold T. Pulsifer, has obtained such a response that its incorporation papers were sent to Albany yesterday under the shortened title of Mercy Ships for Children, Inc.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28-- Several luncheon parties were given today at the Southampton Beach Club, the hostesses and their guests later joining the large gallery at the opening matches of the Fiftieth Invitation Tennis Tournament at the Meadow Club.
PARIS, July 29--The artistic life of France is scattered and suspended but is beginning to gather in order to be ready to organize for a resumution of activity.

A young man of engaging personality and with all of the advantages that a respected family could provide was seized yesterday after a futile attempt to hold up a courageous teller in the Corn Exchange Bank branch at the northeast corner of Ninety-first Street and Broadway, with a toy pistol.

NEW ORLEANS, July 29--Military and commercial aviation of the United States will benefit materially from a five-year study of world-wide weather conditions which have been completed here by the Work Projects Administration's weather bureau project, the only one of its type in the United States.

From the land, from the sky and from the water New York extended an enthusiastic welcome yesterday to the liner America, new queen of the American merchant marine, as she sailed rakishly into her home port on her first passenger carrying run.

Enemy bombers escorted by fighters attacked a harbor (Dover] on the southeast coast this morning. Strong formations of Royal Air Force fighters intercepted the enemy.

Four United States migrants, actual and potential, took the stand before a Congressional investigating committee in the Federal Court Building yesterday and told, for the benefit of legislators who will try to write laws to cope with the problems they personified, the stories of their troubles.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 29--Vic Ghezzi, New Jersey's contribution to the Ryder Cup team, and Ashley T. Cole, his 15-year-old protege, won the second annual pro-junior tourney sponsored by the Jersey P.G.A. and held at the Echo Lake Country Club today.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held within extremely narrow limits again yesterday and ended with losses of 1 to 3 points. Private advices reflected more favorable progress of the new crop. Some selling was assigned to hedging operations against marketing in the South, where the crop is moving in the Southwest.

HAVANA, July 29--Detailed methods by which the American republics may best defend themselves against the possible consequences of the European war were formally approved tonight at a closed plenary session of their foreign ministens.

LONDON, July 29--A few hours after the German radio announced that mass air attacks on Britain were about to start, more than eighty Nazi bombers and fighters made a surprise dive-bombing raid on the port of Dover today, but were beaten off in the fiercest air battle of the war.

ROME, July 29--Premier Mussolini's fifty-seventh birthday and the fortieth anniversary of King Victor Emmanuel's accession to the throne both came today, but only the King's anniversary was celebrated. Even in that case, since it was also forty years ago that King Humbert I was assassinated, all flags were at half staff.
SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, July 29-- Both Yugoslav and Greek Macedonia these days are being subjected to currents of propaganda.

LONDON, July 29--Neville Chamberlain, who in spite of his 71 years and the strain of his long term as Prime Minister, has been free so far from serious illness, underwent a successful operation tonight in a nursing home that he had entered earlier in the day.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29The fiftieth annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament started on the turf courts of the Meadow Club today, with National Champion Robert L. Riggs Jr. of Chicago, winner here for the past three years, at the top of the field of sixty-four players.

DEAL, N.J., July 29--Mrs. Dewitt Untermeyer of the Hollywood Club scored 40, 37--77 and took a one-stroke lead today in the eleventh annual New Jersey Shore fifty-four-hole medal play championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Deal course.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 29 --Rumania, is "willing and ready" to cede territory to Hungary and Bulgaria, it was stated in official quarters tonight.

PARIS (via Berlin), July 29--All vehicles of the American Field Service have returned to Paris in good condition, Said Wayne Chatfield Taylor, European representative of the American Red Cross, in an interview outlining that organization's future activities in France.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP)--Paced by Johnny Mize, who batted in four runs, the Cardinals made their hits count today to beat the Bees, 8 to 3, in the opener of a four-game series and returned to fifth place in the National League.
CHUNGKING, China, July 29-- All-China headquarters of the Chinese Red Cross Medical Relief Corps at Kweiyang was bombed by a squadron of Japanese naval planes yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 29--Supplies of wheat and rye grains, which go to make up bread in Europe, seem to be 5 to 10 per cent under peacetime needs, while feed supplies for cattle will probably be 10 to 15 per cent deficient, the Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations of the Agriculture Department stated today.

For the third consecutive month, new orders placed with manufacturers advanced during June, as measured by the preliminary index of the National Industrial Conference Board. Shipments and inventories showed little change.
Considerable residential renlat activity in Greenwich Village and the East and West Side areas of the midtown section is indicated in reports received yesterday from apartment house brokers.

We are all familiar nowadays with the thought that the United States has passed its point of most rapid growth in population, and is approaching a time when it will cease to grow or will even drop back.

LONDON, July 29--A "brain trust" of four civilians and three generals has been established at the War Office for the purpose of overhauling the administrative system and cutting out red tape, it was announced tonight.
TOKIO, Tuesday, July 30--Foreign residents in Japan read this morning with surprise and alarm a warning issued by the Japanese Army on alleged foreign espionage activities.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 29--The Pequot Yacht Club junior team, sailing the Carolina, tools a lead of 3 points for the Gregory Taylor Challenge Cup today when two of the three races were held in Long Island Sound.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 30 (AP)-- Britain has demanded a full investigation into the death of Melville James Cox, veteran British newspaper man who, Japanese said, committed suicide after his arrest on espionage charges, reliable sources disclosed early today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29--With a beautiful green infield as a setting and one of the largest throngs seen at the clubhouse in many years, the horse racing season here opened this afternoon.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, July 29 (Canadian Press)-- Two transatlantic liners, with 2,000 refugees from the European war zone aboard, docked here for a few hours today, disembarked some of their passengers, and then steamed on toward another port where most of the travelers will enter Canada.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP)--The Tigers were toppled again by the Athletics today and their American League lead was cut to one game. The score was 9--7.

The firmer tone in United States Steel common in the stock market yesterday reflected a widespread expectation that the directors would declare a common dividend, perhaps of $1 a share, at their meeting after the close of trading this afternoon.

SHEATED in his hotel room with all windows wide open, Manager Bill McKechnie of the Reds was keeping cool in a costume that Mahatma Gandhi would have approved. Another thing that helped was that he had practically nothing to worry about--unless it was the world series.
CHICAGO, July 29--Wheat prices fluctuated today in a listless manner within a range of about cent a bushel, with business mainly of a professional character.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)--The Association of American Railroads reported today that net railway operating income of Class I railroads in the first six months of this year totaled $242,366,834, compared with $165,623,219 for the first six months of 1939.

The Rev. George Drew Egbert, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Flushing, Thirty-eighth Avenue and Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens, died yesterday in the Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, after an illness of several months. He was 75 years old. His home was at 38-20 Bowne Street, Flushing.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)-- Labor unions in the newspaper and motion picture industries opposed before the wage-hour administration today employer proposals for redefinition of "executive," "professional" and other terms designating workers exempt from the labor standards law.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 29--German propaganda appears about to bear fruit in a remote section of the Middle East. A Lewisohn Stadium audience of some 7,500 gathered last night to listen in the open air to an opera which remains a work of unique inspiration, Bizet's "Carmen," a perennial favorite, and justly so, with the public.

The Republican campaign headquarters for the East opened yesterday, on a "skeleton" basis, in the Grand Central Terminal Building, 70 East Forty-fifth Street. The headquarters at present occupies a suite on the fifth floor, with ample room for expansion on the same floor.

BERLIN, July 29 (UP)--Today's High Command communique claimed the sinking of another 78,750 tons of British shipping, bringing to more than 200,000 tons the total officially claimed sunk in the last three days.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)--A confidential Navy plan to station towing vessels in every major harbor to lay and tend submarine nets in an emergency was disclosed today by the Defense Commission. With the temperature in the city climbing to 94.3 degrees yesterday' and the humidity unusually high, New Yorkers experienced one of the most uncomfortable days since the heat wave started on July 19.

Dwight Deere Wiman let it be known yesterday that John Van Druten's latest play, "Old Acquaintance," will open its try-out tour at the Wilbur Theatre, Boston, on Monday, Sept. 16. ALBANY, July 30--Organization of plans to survey the State's industry and chart the extent of migration of business advanced today. Naming of committees to undertake the study was almost completed.

Deputy Fire Chief James Tubridy, whose heroism previously had brought him two medals, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital from injuries received in a third action in line of duty three months ago. He was 53 years old.

An American millinery designer presented a collection based 100 per cent on American themes yesterday afternoon. It was Sally Victor. In it she demonstrated her good taste and her sense of humor. Her ideas were drawn from the last century and her guiding star was Brigham Young.

An electric storm could not stop the Dodgers, but the Pirates could and did by an 8-2 margin, under the floodlights at Ebbets Field last night. Thunder, lightning and a heavy downpour threatened to call the whole thing off, but the elements relented just before game time and thereafter it was "Pittsburgh night" in Brooklyn.
COPENHAGEN, German-occupied Denmark, July 29--Denmark, formerly famous for her exports of butter and other agricultural products, now faces the possibility of the introduction of butter rationing.

DEAL, N. J., July 30--Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, by playing the long, hard Hollywood golf course in 43, 38--81 today, gained a one-stroke lead over her nearest competitor when she added her 80 of yesterday for a total of 161 in the eleventh annual women's metropolitan 54-hole medal-play New Jersey Shore tournament.

CHICAGO, July 30--Wheat prices advanced around 1 cents a bushel today to the highest level in three weeks. Mills bought early and absorbed the surplus in the pit and when some of the professional operators who sold early tried to cover short sales in sympathy with the strength in securities they found offerings light.

The evidence was so overwhelmingly against Max Uchansky, 21 years old, at his General Sessions trial in March, 1939, that the jury speedily convicted him in the holdup, two months before, of the Lemberger Synagogue at 256 East Fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The Electric Bond and Share Company scored a strategic victory today in legal manoeuvres incident to formulating a policy of procedure in the "death sentence" proceedings under the Holding Company Act when the Securities and Exchange ...

A banking group composed of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., Smith, Barney Co., Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt and Riter Co. offered to the public yesterday morning a new issue of $3,700,000 Pennsylvania Glass Sand Corporation first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1960.

WASHINGTON July 30--Northam Lee Griggs of New York, formerly of the United States foreign service, will leave New York by clipper tomorrow en route to London, where he will join the American Red Cross committee charged with the distribution in England of Red Cross war relief supplies from this country.

The ten-story store and mercantile building at the southeast corner of Broadway and Great Jones Street, known as 682 Broadway, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of Jesse H. Barkin, lawyer, through Williams Co., brokers, who have been retained by the new owner as agent for the property.

MELBOURNE, July 30 (Australian Associated Press)--The council of the Australian Lawn Tennis Association has rejected Adrian Quist's proposal that he and Jack Bromwich tour the United States, playing exhibition games to aid Australian war funds.

QUEBEC, July 30 (Canadian Press)--Frank Carrel, veteran member of the Quebec Legislative Council for the Gulf Division and former newspaper publisher here, died in hospital today at the age of 69. He had been a member of the Provincial Upper House since 1918.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its net income for the second quarter amounted to $19,201,008, an increase of $17,891,247 over the net of $1,309,761 for the June quarter of 1939.
Total resources of the 140 banks in New York City at the end of June aggregated $24,852,885,732, a new record high, according to the semi-annual compilation of The American Banker.

Democratic party fortunes in California have been profoundly altered by the nomination of Wendell L. Willkie by the Republicans, a recent survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion reveals, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 30-- Declaring that talk of preparedness in 1942 is "folly," Professor Sidney Post Simpson of the Harvard Law School told an American defense meeting at the Harvard Summer School tonight that the deadline for defense preparation in this country would come next April or sooner.

Alfred E. Smith, Democratic nominee for President in 1928, formally announced yesterday that he was taking another "walk" this year and that he would support Wendell L. Willkie, Republican nominee, as he did Alf M. Landon in 1936.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30-- Mrs. Joseph R. Dilworth gave a dinner tonight at the Irving, where she is spending the season, for Mrs. Henry R. Rea of Sewickley, Pa.
The United States Steel Corporation has had few chairmen in its close to forty years of existence, but in its lifetime the policy of the chairmen has been to grant interviews only on request.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30--President Roosevelt tonight rejected the idea that the United States has been defeated in its efforts to maintain "liberal trade principles" and asserted that if it adopted "totalitarian control" over foreign trade it would be taking a step toward economic dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, July 30--Legislation proposed yesterday by President Roosevelt authorizing him to order out the National Guard for training was approved today by the Senate Military Affairs Committee and reported to the Senate.

The accumulation of favorable domestic industrial news finally forced the stock market to break out yesterday from its pinpoint trend, and under the stimulus of the heaviest and broadest trading since June 28, values advanced 1 to 4 points.

LONDON, July 30--While persistent reports circulated in London that Germany was manufacturing large quantities of poisonous gas, Sir John Anderson, Minister of Home Security, warned the British people in a broadcast tonight to practice wearing their masks and be prepared against poisonous gas sprayed by bombers from the air.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 30 (AP) --W.E. Miller's Pioneer Hanover again proved himself the best pacer of the Grand Circuit meeting at Narragansett Park when he won the second division pace of the Trotting Club Stake in straight heats today.
ALGECIRAS, Spain, Wednesday, July 31 (AP)--Five persons were reported killed and fifteen wounded in a raid by Italian bombers yesterday afternoon on Britain's Gibraltar fortress.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened yesterday, influenced by an advance in securities and grains, and despite an increase in hedging operations ended with gains of 4 to 5 points.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30-- Alexander Korda announced today that his next picture will be a screen treatment of the historic love affair of Lord Nelson and Lady Hamilton, with Laurence Olivier ...

Fred Krais, top-seeded entrant and recent winner of the New York State title at Utica, made his first appearance in the metropolitan junior singles championship yesterday at the Terrace Tennis Club in Brooklyn and catapulted into the semi-finals.

The Democratic National Committee will open its campaign headquarters in New York on Aug. 12, Oliver A. Quayle Jr., treasurer, said yesterday after discussions at the Hotel Biltmore with James A. Farley, National Chairman, and Charles Michelson, director of publicity.

There is grave doubt that New York State can maintain the present standards of relief without help from the Federal Government, State Welfare Commissioner David C. Adie testified yesterday before a House of Representatives Committee that is conducting an inquiry into the destitute migrant problem at the Federal Court Building.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP)-- Hugh Mulcahy isn't superstitious, so it's not "jinxing" the tall righthander to say that he may be the first twenty-game winner the Phillies have had in twenty-four years.

A basic three-year agreement between the American Guild of Musical Artists, A.F. of L. affiliate, and the Metropolitan Opera Association has been signed through committees representing both organizations, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The good effect on enrollees of Civilian Conservation Corps camp life was attested in a report made public today by James J. BERLIN, July 30--The recent speech of Dr. Walther Funk, Reich Commissioner General for Economy, on Europe's future economic organization is still being keenly discussed in Berlin government and business circles and in the German press.

The Merchants Association of New York yesterday distributed to its members a notice announcing the rules and regulations for the collection of the Canadian excise tax on newspapers, periodicals and advertising material.

Although the World's Fair continues to show a substantial operating profit, the lag in attendance attributed largely to the current heat wave has made impossible the hoped-for 5 per cent payment to bondholders by Aug. 15, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the board, made known yesterday.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30--Many luncheon and dinner parties were given here today and last night in connection with the races. There was a large addition to the society contingent today.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that traffic over the Bell System's radio telephone circuits to South America and across the Pacific broke all previous records in June, the total number of messages over these routes aggregating 2,000 for the month.

Morris S. Tremaine, Controller, sold yesterday $15,000,000 of New York State serial bonds to finance institutional construction at a net interest cost to the State of 1.4968 per cent, a new low record for comparable issues.
BOSTON, July 30--City Registrar James A. Burke canceled his vacation today because of a rush for marriage licenses surpassing even that of 1917.
LONDON, Wednesday, July 31-- Great Britain enjoyed a comparative lull in Nazi aerial attacks yesterday, but, according to Air Ministry officials, Germany did not ...

With July Army enlistments exceeding by 300 those of any month since the World War, the Second Corps Area, consisting of New York, New Jersey and Delaware, received orders from the War Department yesterday to enlist an additional 1,713 men "as soon as possible."
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 30--Wendell L. Willkie's first audience for his acceptance speech, over which he is now toiling, is his wife.

A miss is as good as a mile, and three missed plays in a wild and complex eighth inning cost the Giants a ball game at the Polo Grounds hothouse yesterday as the Reds pushed over four fantastically contrived runs for a 6-3 victory.

The United States Maritime Commission has completed a series of hearings on the question of manning scales for subsidized vessels and will issue a report on its findings after data gathered by its examiners have been studied.

Dr. Maximilian Goldstein, heart specialist, who recently won a reversal of his conviction of insurance fraud and then was convicted again on similar charges, was sentenced yesterday to fifteen months in prison. His sentence on the upset conviction had been a year and a day.

After a special meeting yesterday the administrative committee of City College delayed action on the election of Dr. Dexter M. Keezer, president of Reed College in Portland, Ore., as president of the city institution.

VICHY, France, July 30--The maximum penalty for crimes against the State and other abuse of public office will be life imprisonment, under a decree adopted tonight by the Council of Ministers. The decree creates a permanent Supreme Court of Justice to try such cases. There will be no appeal from its decisions.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 30 (AP) --The Newark Bears crept within two games of the International League-leading Rochester Red Wings by capturing both ends of a double-header tonight.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30 --Mrs. Joseph Reynolds Guernsey and Mrs. William Whittingham Battie gave a luncheon today at the Maidstone Club for the former's niece.

The real job facing salesmanship today is to sell America and its form of government to Americans, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia yesterday told about 500 members and guests of the Sales Executives Club of New York at a luncheon held in the Aviation Terrace Restaurant of the Administration Building at La Guardia Field, North Beach.

Wilbur R. Kimball, electrical and aircraft inventor, who was associated in his youth with Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas A. Edison, died late Monday night in St. Luke's Hospital of organic maladies, it was learned yesterday. His age was 77.

When Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne officially renames the Sherburne Pheasant Farm at Sherburne, N.Y., on Saturday, it is quite likely that the occasion will recall many pleasant visits to him.

The two three-story apartment houses at 20 School Street and 21 Edna Street, Baldwin, Nassau County, have been sold by Cahn Cahn, operators, to Edwin L. James, of 1957 Lurting Avenue, the Bronx, an investor.

LONDON, July 30--The stock markets were unsettled today by the renewed deterioration of AngloJapanese relations so soon after the effort to placate Japan by closing the Burma Road. Early firmness surrendered to some selling at lower prices though business was on a small scale.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,690,400 barrels, an increase of 110,050 over the 3,580,350 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 62,000 barrels in excess of the calculation of 3,628,400 daily by the Bureau of Mines for July.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 30--Wendell L. Willkie today added the names of Samuel Seabury and Alfred E. Smith to the list of prominent anti-New Deal Democrats who have publicly announced their support for him since the thirdterm nomination of President Roosevelt.

Whether there should be a warprofits tax, an excess-profits tax, or both, depends on the revenues required, it was declared yesterday in a memorandum to the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation in Washington by the committee on Federal taxation of the American Institute of Accountants.

WASHINGTON, July 30--Securities registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission which became effective in the first six months of the current year, and which were proposed for sale by issuers were valued at $667,191,000, compared with $734,362,000 in the first half of 1939, the SEC announced today.

The New York Stock Exchange has abandoned its opposition to the application of United Stockyards Corporation to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the delisting of its preferred stock on the Exchange, it appears from a letter dated July 24 from the Exchange to the commission which was made public yesterday.

SCHUYLER FALLS, N.Y., July 30--John L. Roberge, 42 years old, of 320 Second Street, Union City, N.J., who served in the Marine Corps in the World War, died suddenly from a heart attack early this afternoon in a sham battle for Burnt Mountain here.
DETROIT, July 30--Charley Ruffing exploded his first home run of the campaign at Briggs Stadium today and supplied the punch that gave a temporary jar to the pennant aspirations of the Tigers.

VICHY, France, July 30 (AP)--The French Government announced today that it had protested "energetically" to the British Government over internment of Admirals Cayol and Villanine, commanders of French ships that were in English ports when the French-German armistice was signed last month.
Favorable earnings for the first six months of this year were announced by three aviation companies.
To speed the emergency training program, the Board of Education voted yesterday to exempt 380 teachers and four high school principals from the provisions of the dual job law.
Three portable X-ray machines for British base hospitals will be bought with $1,500 contributed yesterday to Bundles for Britain, 484 Park Avenue.

Criticizing the City Planning Commission as a bureaucratic agency, members of the Democratic majority in the City Council adopted a resolution yesterday to amend the City Charter so as to restrict the powers now exercised by the Commission.

Earle Wood Evans of Wichita, Kan., a former president of the American Bar Association and a director of corporations, died suddenly yesterday afternoon at the conclusion of a meeting of the Santa Fe Railroad's board of directors, of which he was a member.

The Colonial Trust Company's exhibit of historic checks of famous Americans, which has just completed an exhibition tour throughout the country with brief showing in banks in many cities, is now on display at the Colonial's branch at Fifth Avenue and Thirtieth Street.

For the forty-third day yesterday German planes blasted at British objectives and British planes bombed the Ruhr. For the fortythird day since the Campaign of Britain started on the night of June 18-19 civilians suffered or died, men fought in mid-air and the wreckage of flaming planes plummeted to earth or sea.

LONDON, July 30 (UP)--British informants said tonight that the Duke and Duchess of Windsor likely would change their plans for crossing the Atlantic because their purported date of departure had been revealed and theoretically at least they are liable to seizure by the Germans.

Yesterday, Monday, our bombers made daylight raids over a widespread area in Germany and the Low Countries. A large supply ship was damaged near Flushing. Barges and other vessels were hit at Emden and Hamburg and off the island of Terschelling.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 30-- Working with speed and precision, a gang of thugs held up and robbed a bank messenger and his guard outside the Postoffice here at 10:50 A.M. today of $108,000 that was being taken to the Postoffice for shipment to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
A net income of $1,701,375 after all charges was reported yesterday by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for the twelve months ended on June 30.

In order to provide equivalent American hemes for the poorer children in the British cross section that will soon be on its way here, the United States Committee for the Care of European Children yesterday called on its 172 local branches to enlist the greatest possible number of persons willing to sponsor an unknown child financially in an unknown American home that could not otherwise receive the child.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 30-- Berkshire Museum officers at Pittsfield held this evening their annual members' night to mark the opening of an exhibition of Shaker art and craftmanship, lent and exhibited by Dr. and Mrs. Edward Deming Andrews; also a display of sixty-three oils, water-colors and drawings by Martin Mower, retired Harvard professor.

STRASBOURG, German-Occupied France, July 31--Silent and empty across the plains and hills of AlsaceLorraine stretch the deserted fortresses of the Maginot Line. Some of them are shattered ruins with gaping holes in their ten-foot concrete walls.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 (UP)--The local gendarmes have put the pure and simple quietus on the dancing bones and the whirling wheel in the gilded halls of chance in this fashionable spa.

LONDON, July 31--Trading in most sections continued listless in today's stock market. Small losses were general among the gilt-edge securities. Further declines in Japanese bonds reflected the political tension in the Far East but Chinese issues improved.

VICHY, France, July 31--A feeling of isolation from the outside world persists here, making the situation seem even more unreal. There are newspapers, of course-- quite a number--but they are single sheets with little news from abroad, especially from America.

HOLLYWOOD, July 31 (AP)--Loretta Young, who at 27 is a veteran of thirteen years in motion pictures, and Thomas H. Lewis, 38, radio advertising executive, were married today in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Westwood. The ceremony was witnessed only by members of the two families and close friends.
Sable-blend muskrats continued to lead in volume-selling merchandise in the August fur sales in many cities throughout the country.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--The plan to have the nation's medical facilities organized and ready in event of war was extended to each State today with the naming of fifty chairmen to help direct the work.

CHICAGO, July 31--Major Gen. Carlos E. Black, who retired last year after having been Adjutant General of Illinois since 1922, died today in St. John's Hospital in Springfield of a heart ailment at the age of 64. He had been in ill health since suffering a heart attack a year ago.

A plot of vacant land, 260 by 300 feet, on the southwest side of New Jersey State Highway 29 in Hillside, N.J., has been purchased by Bo Adlerbert, trading as the Sunrise Dairy, as the site for a pasteurizing plant.

An underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation will put on the market today a new issue of 180,000 shares of 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Narragansett Electric Company. ALBANY, July 31--The Public Service Commission announced today that on Aug. 9 it would begin a new investigation into the propriety and reasonableness of the rates charged by the New York State Gas and Electric Corporation, a unit of the Associated Gas and Electric system.

ROME, July 31--The defeat of Great Britain must be a slow process in which the present tactics of bombing factories and ports and torpedoing ships must continue for some time, says Virginio Gayda in an editorial in the Giornale d'Italia today.
Profit taking and the failure of the public to participate more heavily in trading brought a technical reaction yesterday in the stock market and an easing of values.

ALGECIRAS, Spain, July 31 (AP)-- Gibraltar was heavily bombed late this afternoon. Taking advantage of scattered clouds, an undetermined number of planes, believed to have been Italian, dropped several bombs.

Definitive bonds and debentures of the Toledo Edison Company are available for delivery in exchange for the temporary forms, it was announced yesterday by the banks which acted as agents in the respective issues.

John J. Knewitz, Bronx County Republican leader, heads the list of new appointees to the Republican State Executive Committee, the personnel of which was announced yesterday by State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle at State headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.

SALEM, N.H., July 31 (AP)--Mrs. N. Knightson Beal's Hardy Bud, a 6-to-1 shot, proved a surprise winner today at Rockingham Park in the Salem Stakes, $2,500 added race for 2-year-old fillies. It was the first stake of the Summer meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Redrafting of legislation designed to grant to the Export-Import Bank $500,000,000 more with which to make loans to Latin-American countries to help them meet the war situation was ordered today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)--The American Red Cross is rushing an average of 850,000 pounds of supplies daily to millions of suffering Europeans. Despite submarines, air bombers, blockades and mines, it has not lost a cargo.
