WASHINGTON, July 31--Both Attorney General Jackson and the National Defense Advisory Commission made a formal announcement late today that the filing of an anti-trust suit against major oil companies and their subsidiaries has been held up until the commission could see how far it would affect the national defense program.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--The Athletics defeated the White Sox, 4 to 3, tonight, the loss again preventing Chicago from catching the Yankees in their fight for fourth place. The victory enabled Philadelphia to climb out of the American League cellar, a half game ahead of the Browns.

The New York State law requires the banks to have published each year in August or September all accounts of $10 or more that have remained unclaimed for at least fifteen years. The annual treasure hunt will begin today.

The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the second quarter of this year, made public yesterday by Edward L. Shea, president, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $5,132,800.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 1--Arrests of foreigners on espionage charges are continuing. The Foreign Office spokesman, Yakichiro Suma, told the Japanese press the round-up had been made expressly to eliminate persons and organizations that had been spying on military secrets.

LONDON, July 31--Some time ago speculation arose when the Petain government decided to send former Vice Premier Chautemps immediately on a special mission to Brazil. Evidence is now available in London indicating the connection of that mission with a plan for a monarchist restoration in France.

LONDON, July 31--Prime Minister Winston Churchill visited the coastal defenses of Northeast England today. He was accompanied by high staff officers and was cheered wherever he went.

WASHINGTON, July 31--President Roosevelt signed today the bill to start the $68,500,000 national defense program of the Tennessee Valley Authority. CHICAGO, July 31--Wheat showed a firm undertone in the early trading today and at one time prices wet a about cent a bushel higher, going into new ground on the current movement.

Novelty, which is apparently the middle name of the Ballet Theatre, was much in evidence at the Stadium last night when that up-andcoming organization gave the first of its final pair of performances in the Summer season.

From an entry list of 625 pieces of handiwork submitted by women in this area winners in ten classifications were selected yesterday to compete in a nation-wide contest which will be held at the New York World's Fair. The judging was held in the executive offices of R.H. Macy Co., one of eleven stores in the country designated as centers for the elimination contests.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--It became known here today that at least one of the approaches to Wendell L. Willkie. with the object of getting a "clearance" for the President on delicate steps in foreign policy, was made by Archibald MacLeish, the Librarian of Congress.

Two more WPA employee, one of them Maxwell Bodenheim, author and poet, have been suspended pending investigation to determine whether they fraudulently signed affidavits denying membership in the Communist party, it became known yesterday.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange continued limited yesterday with sufficient hedging pressure to supply contracts needed for routine mill calling and leave the list unchanged to 2 points lower than on Wednesday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1-- It has come to pass in this best of tennis seasons in recent years that match point is just another point. Count that match as commonplace in which victory is not snatched on the very precipice of defeat.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1 (AP)-- Governor Preritice Cooper and Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, serving his fourth term in the Senate, piled up impressive leads over their opponents tonight in early returns from today's Democratic primary election.

Three faculty members of Adelphi College, heads of their departments, who were dismissed last semester after a general reorganization program, are bringing damage suits of $20,000 each against the college administration, it became known yesterday.

The unprecedented legal question of where a man's beard ends and where his constitutional rights begin was presented to Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor yesterday as the latest development in the fantastic inquiry into the murder-bycontract ring in Brooklyn.

Johnson Olsen, of Great Neck, well known as builders, have contracted to buy the former estate of Jesse Livermore, Wall Street operator, from the Manufacturers Trust Company in a deal negotiated by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1--Holders of boxes had many guests tonight at the opening concert of the seventh annual Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood.

Former Representative Charles Pope Caldwell, member of the House Military Affairs Committee during the World War and former associate justice of the Court of Special Sessions here, died Wednesday night in his home at 41-11 Fortieth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

DETROIT, Aug. 1--The Tigers really did a job on the Yankees today. While 16,440 fans yelled lusty encouragement, Del Baker's boys broke out in a rash of extra-base hits against Marvin Breuer and Atley Donald to sink the tottering champions, 11 to 2, and nudge them into the second division.
Trading along the West Side of Manhattan as far north as Washington Heights was featured yesterday by sales of apartment houses.

Montauk anglers enjoyed one of the best fishing days of the season as school tuna were taken in large numbers yesterday. The offshore fleet finally swung into action with a rush as the tuna provided the means for what Walt Willis described as a field day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1--Interest in the wheat market was at a low ebb today with prices holding within a range of about cent a bushel. There was nothing in the general run of the news that attracted much attention.
Two taxpayers were among the properties figuring in Long Island realty deals reported yesterday.

The financial problem of bringing refugee children here from Great Britain was described by Marshall Field and Erich H. Biddle at a luncheon given here yesterday by the United States Committee for the Care of European Children, It is simple.
LONDON, Aug. 1--The advent of the new Japanese Government, which is believed here to be dominated by the military, is expected to terminate burgeoning British efforts at conciliation in the Far East.

Bank clearings for the twentythree leading cities of the country in the week ended on July 31 were $4,745,932,000, a decline of 14.2 per cent from the $5,529,348,000 in the corresponding period in 1939, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The decline was ascribed partly to the fact that first-of-the-month settlements were included in last year's total.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 1-- A pair of New Jersey amateurs, tall, willowy Phil Axt and stocky, medium-sized Dom Morano, representing the Forest Hill Field Club of Bloomfield, today showed the other teams competing in the eighth John G. Anderson memorial tourney, annual fixture at the Winged Foot Club, just how bestball golf should be played.

Identical slates for county-wide judicial offices to be filled at this Fall's elections were chosen yesterday by the Tammany Executive Committee and the Republican County Executive Committee meeting one hour apart.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1--Philip Murray, vice president of the C.I.O., today told the convention of the United Automobile Workers of America that there did not seem to be any need at this time for passage of a conscription law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1--Chicago's 1940 White Sox "walked" into the first division of the American League for the first time today. With the bases loaded in the eleventh inning, Nelson Potter, Athletics' pitcher, walked Joe Kuhel to force Bob Kennedy across with the run that gave the Sox a 5-to-4 triumph.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including G.M.P. Murphy Co. and R. F. Griggs Company won yesterday the award of $780,000 of refunding bonds of Bridgeport, Conn., on a bid of 100.188 for 1 s.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Much of the opposition to the Burke-Wadsworth bill to conscript a national defense Army springs from sincere conviction. But a good deal has its source in the politics of the Presidential year which has been deeply intensified by the third-term issue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Underwriting participations for thirtyseven registered issues offered for sale in the second quarter of 1940 amounted to $285,464,000, compared with $365,533,000 for forty-two issues offered for sale in the first quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the new Revenue Act of 1940 have beet made against earnings in many reports. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final adjustments.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1--Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton gave a dinner tonight for Mrs. James Tilly Houghton of New York, Mrs. Silas B. Mason of Lexington, Ky.; Mr.. and Mrs. L. Rodman Mack of Loudonville, N.Y.; William H. Lipscomb of Washington, D.C., and Carter Bowie of New York.

VENTNOR, N.J., Aug. 1--The large auditorium dominating the ocean side of this resort's $130,000 municipal pier was destroyed and other parts of the structure were damaged by a spectacular fire this morning. Mayor Harry Hodson estimated the loss at $100,000 and said most of it was covered by insurance.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 1--The doubtful legality of the Mexican Presidential election was again brought to the fore by decision reached by both the Avila Camacho and Almazan parties to file complaints with the Mexican Attorney General charging their opponents committed grave irregularities on July 7.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 1--Henrik Shipstead, who has represented Minnesota in the United States Senate as a Farmer-Laborite for the past 18 years, filed today as a candidate for the Republican nomination at the Sept. 10 primary.
Fur imports rose 39 per cent during June, although skin sales declined in comparison with the same month last year, according to fig ures issued yesterday by the American Fur Merchants Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Panama Canal Zone has conducted a thorough "house-cleaning" and has rounded up and detained eighty-one foreign agents who were illegally in the zone, Secretary Stimson announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)--Out of the welter of figures on warplane purchases by the government have begun to emerge certain evidences of the scheme which the Army and Navy have in formulation for the air defense of the Western Hemisphere.
Mrs. M. de Zaldo de Acosta departs today for a brief visit in Newport, R.I.

Officials of the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation announced yesterday that they had begun an educational program to acquaint wholesale and retail food dealers and relief recipients with the elements of the food-stamp plan in preparation for its introduotion into the Borough of Brooklyn on Sept. 3

Two hundred and forty lots bordering on Wood Avenue in the three Union County, N.J., communities of Linden, Roselle and Cranford have been bought by Berlant Park Homes, headed by Harry Ziegler, builder, who plans a development of moderate-priced homes. Albert M. Greenfield Co. sold the property for the Montifore Building and Loan Association.

LONDON, Aug. 1--King George and Queen Elizabeth toured the East Midlands district of England today visiting families whose houses had just been destroyed by a bombing raid, inspecting coastal antiinvasion defenses and reviewing work being done by troops and munitions workers.

BERLIN, Aug. 1--Official quarters here have maintained complete silence on the results of the Havana conference. But there is little doubt that United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull's accomplishments there are viewed as quite satisfactory from the American point of view.

One hundred and seventy-eight men and women employes of the Court of General Sessions, including clerks and attendants and the clerks and investigators of the probation department, received yesterday $43,368 in addition to their July salaries.

A caravan of automobiles with American representatives of industrial and trade organizations will leave on a good-will tour to Central and South America this Fall, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Dunn, a lawyer at 295 Madison Avenue.

ALBANY, Aug. 1--Governor Lehman, in an action unprecedented in peacetime, today appointed a State Council of National Defense to advise him on all matters pertaining to the national preparedness program as applied to the State of New York.

LYON, France, Aug 1--Here in Lyon it is easier to understand what has happened and is happening to France than it is in Vichy. For the temperature of Vichy is inevitably above normal and a view of the situation as a whole is obscured by momentary rumor and each hour's events. Here one gets nearer realities.

Premier Molotoff's speech before the Supreme Soviet yesterday contains no surprises. The masters of the Kremlin continue to survey the secular scene with a cynical detachment which allows them to celebrate great victories in a war in which they insist they take no part.

Hearings of a House committee in this city and in New Jersey have reminded the public that the problem of the penniless migratory worker exists here, just as it does in California.

Shirt-sleeved professors, school executives and teachers, on an afternoon's leave from Columbia University's Teachers College, lolled yesterday on a tree-shaded hill in a suburb and marked the first steak-less version of the college's traditional men's steak dinner by dining on hot dogs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--An immediate interim rate cut of $3,750,000, the largest ever ordered by the Federal Power Commission, has been demanded from the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America and the Texoma Natural Gas Company, the F. P. C. announced today.

Composite figures of the mutual savings banks in the United States for the six months ended June 30 show new record highs in deposits, total assets and the number of depositors, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks announced yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1-- "Hellzapoppin," Olsen and Johnson Broadway success has been purchased by Jules Levey's Mayfair productions, a Universal unit, for $200,000 the studio announced today.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 1.(AP)--Properties of the bankrupt Mobile Ohio Railroad were sold today at public auction for $13,411,915, with all but $15 going to the bondholders' reorganization committee of the road.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 1-- William Allen White, conferring here today with Wendell L. Willkie on foreign policy, predicted that a Republican victory was "in the stars" this Fall and that there was an obvious drift of independent voters away from President Roosevelt.

The statement of the United States Rubber Company for the six months ended on June 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $4,234,239 after all charges, taxes, reserves and a loss of $437,345 on the sale of its former general office building.

GRENOBLE, France, Aug. 1 (UP) -German armies occupying France tonight were reported in motion from the Spanish border to the Belgian frontier, moving toward the French Channel seaports facing the British Isles, under conditions of secrecy.
A banking group headed by Paul H. Davis Co. will offer publicly today 62,000 shares of common stock of the Woodward Governor Company of Rockford, Ill., at $13.50 each.

AKRON, Aug. 1--An engineman's mental lapse was blamed by Pennsylvania Railroad officials today for a head-on collision of a gasolineelectric railroad coach and a doubleheader freight train in which fortythree persons met flaming death.

Several hundred persons, including officials and members of the New York Fire Department, attended the eighth annual memorial mass of requiem yesterday for eight members of the department who were killed in a fire at the Ritz Tower Hotel eight years ago.

Arnold Pomerantz, pianist and former child prodigy, who had been soloist at the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts for young people, died early yesterday morning in his home at 25 Central Park West, after a long illness, at the age of 19.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Smith Committee to Investigate the National Labor Relations Board accused the board today of evading the "plain mandate of Congress" to abolish its Economic Research Division by merely changing its name to the Technical Service Division.

The completion of sixty years as a Redemptorist, using the Bohemian language, will be celebrated at a high mass at 6 A.M. today at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 321 East Sixty-first Street, by the Rev. Edward J. Hornung of the parish staff.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1--Contracts were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today on denim working hats and cotton filled comforters, and bids were opened on additional textile supplies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Senator Ernest Lundeen of Minnesota called today for a third party convention to meet in Chicago and draw up a platform opposing "the interventionist policy" of the two major parties.

After thirty years as the family residence, the four-story dwelling at 22 East Ninety-third Street has been sold by the heirs of Edwin Rubin to the 22 East Ninety-third Street Company. The sale was negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, who arranged a mortgage of $20,000 for ten years.

Drum, commander of the First Army and the Second Corps Area, gave the principal address today to his "buddies" at the closing exercises of the Citizens Military Training Camp, and the 1,900 young men also received high praise for their soldiering ability from Colonel James I. Muir, commander of the Twenty-sixth Infantry garrison here.

Samuel F. Pryor Jr., Eastern campaign director, and Oren Root Jr., chairman of the Associated Willkie Clubs of America, left yesterday in separate airplanes to confer today with Wendell L. Willkie, Republican nominee for President, at Colorado Springs.

Commissioner William F. Carey of the Department of Sanitation announced yesterday his intention to resign his $10,000 post to accept appointment to a $4,000 job as superintendent of landfills in his own department, a position for which he has qualified by attaining top rank in a competitive civil service examination.

LONDON, Aug. 2--Farmers and other residents of South and Southwest England and Wales who looked up along the beams of searchlights early this morning and saw clouds of leaflets fluttering down are now in possession of Hitlerian documents that eventually may exceed in value first-edition copies of Mein Kampf.

ROME, Aug. 2--An important battle between Italian planes and a large British squadron was fought just south of the Balearics yesterday, according to today's Italian war bulletin. Some of the British units were hit, it is claimed. At the other end of the Mediterranean last night an Italian destroyer ran down and sank the British submarine Oswald, taking prisoner fifty-two members of the Oswald's crew of fifty-five, the communique says.

OTTAWA, Aug. 3--Starting Oct. 1, 30,000 single men will report for compulsory military training every month in Canada. The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,216,624,859 in July, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price per share of all listed stocks on July 31 was $27.51, compared with $26.74 a month previous.
